headline: Decent, the job is what you make it
pros:
-> the benefits are great, and you get them even as a part-timer!!
-> pay is okay
-> call center is MUCH better than branch environment-wise
-> WFH options expanding with the contact center
-> it's not what you'd expect from a call centre, I genuinely love this work, but it is what you make it!
-> bonuses are pretty good at the contact centre! Branch bonuses less so.
cons:
-> chronically understaffed
-> always try to squeeze more and more out of less employees rather than just hiring an adequate amount of staff 
-> pay is ok, but it's on the low end compared to the other banks
-> they talk the talk, but often don't walk the walk when it comes to supporting employees
-> they have no drive or concern about retention of good employees a lot of the time

headline: Very fast paced
pros:
1. If you have a supportive manager you’ll do great
2. Meet wonderful people to work with mostly
3. Can make good bonus if really successful. Doing 100% of goal will not cut it. Need at least 200%
cons:
1. Recently started tracking everything and taking off points from our scorecard for not meeting silly goals such as call, meeting, advise+. You will feel demotivated especially if you’re doing well sales wise because the deductions are a lot.
2. The workload is a lot. Customers downtown are really demanding. They want a response immediately. You’re assigned 500-600 customer plus walk in and other advisors clients.
3. Very high turnover as no one can stand the pressure. Then takes forever to replace which puts pressure on remaining advisors.

headline: Racism, intolerance to other cultures and nationalities, lack of advancement
pros: Benefits, HR team, family support, mental health benefits.
cons:
Advancement based on personal empathy, not merits and contribution.
Hidden racism and intolerance to other cultures and nationalities. lack of continuing education. You are just a number, a bolt in a huge machine. Will NOT retain you as a an employee and will replace you in a blink of an eye. District management is a complete disaster and afraid of strong people, looking for weak personalities ready to obey any order. Two great leaders and managers left the bank and that was a huge loss after which everything just went downhill. Stop promoting diversity and inclusion when there is no such thing at your bank. Just using those for marketing purposes. Heard from the new management that bank has to hire certain % of people of different races, color and nationality, which is THE most racist thing ever heard. Disappointed in the company and its culture... Found a way better place where I can keep my personality. So thank you BNS for opening my eyes, giving me valuable lessons and giving me am opportunity to find a way better place to work.

seen the stress before , but that should go to the higher management because they are well paid! not to the peasant that work daily with pennies earned!

headline: Great team & lots of opportunity

headline: Though they may be achieviable, there is constant Pressure to meet your goals
pros:
> training period is long (3 months), giving you a lot of time to get used to.
> if you are lucky and get a team of hardworking and collaborative synergy, you'll get lots of support.
> you get vacation as soon as you start (though not many days)
> through practise and as requirement of the job, you learn A LOT about everything when it comes to personal financial planning. MTG, LOC, REFI, INVESTING, BUDGETING. Honestly, all the essentials.
cons:
> constant pressure, did you meet your call target? did you meet your sales target, did you get enough customer reviews and why they are not 10s? 
> you learn through initiating a learning opportunity yourself. Otherwise, nobody comes to you to say "hey let me teach you this, that". I would have to ask colleagues to sit in their meetings so I can learn from them. Thank goodness there were few nice ones that allowed me to.
> pay is very low compared to the stress that you take on. My base was 59 at the time, 67 with bonus. But it wasnt worth it man.

headline: branch AM
pros: atmosphere, colleagues, environment, pace, clear expectations
cons:
executive levels managements are out of touch of reality.
A lot of push to share only success stories which does lead to creating a fake culture via internal employee social media "workplace". Regional and area leaders need to genuinely care for their subordinates vs only playing politics and think about their vertical and lateral moves

headline: Good vacation days
pros: There are good vacation days here. 16 days + 5 personal off days, and of you don't use all the days they can carry over to the next year. I feel like Scotiabank overall cares about employee mental health and getting good rest that we need.
cons: It really depends which department you work in to see what is a good environment. I worked in Wealth management and it can easily become toxic (depending who you work with). I moved to back office different field (AML) and department and it's been a great experience!! Everyone is so supportive and when they are short-staffed they get the help they need! ScotiaWealth was "cheap", they would give one person a 3 person job instead of rehiring...

There’s no real care for employees experience and employees well-being. Management needs better training. You will burn out quickly here.

headline: Prepare to feel like a fool.
pros: great benefits, branch colleagues and atmosphere is supportive even though everyone is overworked and does not have time to help.
cons: 'job aids' are outdated, incorrect, or at best only make sense once you know what you're doing and just need a reminder. Training focused on soft skills, no real training on products or systems. The what and how of your role are expected to be picked up through trial and error... with clients!! I understand that this may sound like i'm the problem but the issue truly is the lack of training. There is no clear answer for any system or product questions and I understand why they recommend you just jump in and learn on the job-it's faster that way. Unfortunately, that means that you look like a fool in front of clients a lot and have to learn to bs people so that you can buy yourself more time to figure out how to best help them. Not a very positive experience.

headline: Bullying in the workplace

cons: Scotiabank will let it's branch managers bully their staff until they need to go on stress leave or quit. This is a terrible place to work I would never recommend it to anyone

headline: Lots of stress and pressure with differ goal measures
pros:
- Big, well known company
- I met some really great managers and co-workers that I will keep in contact for rest of my life
- Lots of opportunities if you are good with your work and have a good relationship with manager
cons:
- depends on the manager, mine is standard stupid and industrious type, makes all of his teams work for useless stuff 
- you have targets on sales, #of meetings, #of calls, #of advice plans and your manager share them with whole team every few days which I find almost insulting to the ones who does not meet their goals with the tone and non-verbal gesture the manager shows. 
- frequent policy changes 
- most things needs to me printed, signed, and scanned, wasting paper and time. 
- frequent system errors and extremely hard to use and learn about it
- pays much more (around $10k more per year) to external hires with less experience compare to internal ones with proven sales skills and good quality of work. 
- all about politics if you want to move up

Lots of the I.T. activities are being moved to Colombia. Remember, this is a bank. All they care for is making profits. If it means laying off half of their personnel, they will do it.

Systems are very easy to use.
cons: Long hours usually staying late for work and not paid under time, unless you have a manager who recognizes this and lets you leave early. It can be very competitive. headline: Opportunities
pros: It's very good if you are looking for a job that offers you opportunities to grow, I started as a teller there and they promoted me to Financial Advisor in a matter of months. I like the experience and they have really good benefit plans and everything. I didn't need too much experience to get the role, as long as you are motivated and a hard worker, they will give you a chance. Also, the people I worked with were amazing to me, they value everyone and they don't allow discrimination.
cons:
The training was nice at first, they do try to support you the entire time, but it was hard for them to do so as they were short-staffed. And the company only cares about you achieving your goals; even if you work overtime and do your best if your goals aren't met (for reasons that aren't your fault) it doesn't look too good for you. They tell you you are not a seller you are an advisor but really by the end of the day you are a seller that has to achieve sales goals.
I worked in 2 different branches and the experience was different from one to another, one was a lot better than the other and that is mostly because of the employees.

headline: Don't Reccomend
pros: Was able to be flexible with my schooling schedule. Room for working your way up.
cons: Low salary compared to other large banks. No proper training system in place but are monitored as if you received the information you needed to properly perform your job from the moment you start. Upper management/executives/HR horribly out of touch with how ground floor operations actually work which impact many functions of day-to-day operations. Stats used for performance reviews/salary increase considerations/bonus considerations are not relevant to someones actual performance on the job (on the service side) - ex. survey goes out asking customers to rate scotiabank as a whole after service, however internally is is a rating of the individual employee that helped them, and as you can imagine there are many people who simply hate banks scoring 1/10 which has nothing to do with employees servicing capabilities. Overall I do not recommend.

headline: GWRT: small teams + old infrastructure + messy management = burnout
pros: Easily recognized company across the globe.
cons:
Everyone was part of multiple projects, so multitasking created little delivery throughput.
Tight regulatory deadlines on a project with old technologies whose original team had left. This lead to insane overtime for the two devs and two BAs working on the SIDAC Brexit project, because we had to reverse engineer the existing solution to build the knowledge from scratch. These deadlines were never discussed with the developers, and giving an assessment was nigh impossible due to the lack of knowledge.
Disregard for the mental and physical wellbeing of the team when put through the 2 month+ crunch period.
Unattentive management that would not listen to alerts from the devs when a possible showstopper was found.
Devs work on BAU, projects, production support, and side work that was unaccounted for, which meant little chance to focus.
Over time was encouraged, then expected, and finally enforced, when the deadlines were not met.
Requests to move to a different project are seldom listened to.
HR is not aware of these operational exploitation situations, so they can
Understaffed infrastructure team would create bottlenecks in the projects, at the cost of its members sleep and vacation.
Little architectural oversight lead to software solutions that derailed from the bigger picture.
Old technologies, such as Java 6, shell scripts for ETLs, out-of-support software and hardware meant that, on top of all the regular BAU, project, and support work, devs would need to coordinate migration projects to newer technologies, which are already outdated at the moment, just to comply with the bare minimum standards.
High turnover rate due to the aforementioned circumstances and work environment.
No opportunities to learn from other teams' strategies or internal knowledge bases, as well as no time to do courses for personal and professional growth within the offered platforms.

All of these observations apply to the Colombia office, as well as the Toronto and SIDAC/BNSL offices. I saw teams working every day 12h+ shifts across the board (talking to team members at 4PM EST meant the UK team was working till 10PM GMT).

headline: STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE IF YOU VALUE YOUR MENTAL HEALTH
pros:
- Great benefits package.
- IF YOU'RE LUCKY, you may meet some decent people.
cons:
- Extremely toxic working environment.

- Management is incompetent and quick to place the blame on anyone to save themselves. Like the management is actually a joke. 

- You are completely on your own. People do not have your back whatsoever. God, forbid you make a mistake you will have a target on your back for as long as you work there and will essentially be nixed for further opportunities (straight from the mouth of employee relations)

- HR & Employee Relations are clearly designed to protect management and people who have been there for a long time. Which makes no sense because the management isn't even worth protecting. The incompetence is actually mind-boggling. 

- Don't listen to a word they say about "supporting mental health". If anything they are the cause of mental health issues amongst employees.

- If you want to get anywhere in Scotiabank, be prepared to play the game, kiss up to management and DON'T MAKE ANY MISTAKES. Ever. Good luck :)

headline: Poor pay compared to responsibilities

headline: Metrics Are Everything
pros:
- Free Account/No Annual Credit Card Fee
- That's about it but I needed more words
cons:
- Every second counts, so you're not expected to hold genuine conversation
- Every employee is placed on a review at the start, to be coached about their metrics ex: target call duration is 5 minutes, when most calls take longer
- The management are totally out of touch with how to handle upset customers, and are often unavailable
- Senior managers bully supervisors and the advisors they're responsible for because the metrics affect their bonuses
- Meetings are brief, you're not allowed to ask questions, but instead told to send an email which may never get a response
- People are extremely competitive, so it's hard to make friends (don't open up to anyone)

headline: Toxic fear based bosses valued for achieving results
pros: There are some awesome people working across the Bank that are great to work with. The pay is good and so are the benefits. The Bank is also doing great things in the community, especially during the pandemic.
cons: Some executives operate much like a high school popularity hierarchy spreading gossip about other people and creating a culture of competition, fear, and distrust. People are promoted to leadership positions with little to no leadership competencies resulting in many toxic hotspots across the organization. Toxic bosses are valued because they get results. Executives say they care about mental health yet pile on work and increase expectations while not considering the pandemic, working from home and family-life. Many people are feeling burnt out and morale is low as they are letting people go all across the Bank. Many colleagues who have worked for other FIs say Scotia is the worst for work/life balance. People are over capacity and still being asked to stretch themselves. While they've made some good strides in advancing more Women to higher level roles (VP+), most of these Women are White and there is hardly any representation of diverse backgrounds on the Executive team or Board with the majority being White Straight Cis Men.

pros: You can pick extra hours and you get 1.5 times pay for working overtime.

Working here was awful. It's a soul crushing job with very poor pay. Scotiabank does not believe in free speech. You are constantly told what to say on the call. If you do not comply you will be coached about it..

I left the company recently. Was very disappointed with how Scotiabank responded to the pandemic. They increased their fees, gave almost no interest on investment accounts, and payment deferrals on products such as mortgages were not free.. many employees also did not receive salary raises during this stressful time.

headline: Not a very inclusive workplace
pros:
- Large organization with ample opportunity grow within the company, whether it 
 is in Canada or internationally
- Good job security (if you are permanent staff)
cons:
Lack of diversity specifically related to gender. I found myself being the only male worker in a women dominated area/field. I often questioned the bank's diversity and inclusive culture and hiring practices. I also noticed women only referring women to any openings that came up, mainly their friends within the organization. It was rather difficult for me to fit in and caused me to deteriorate mentally. Feeling isolated and not being welcome to conversations, lunches, etc being the "guy" 

- Low compensation (I believe other Canadian banks pay low as well) compared to non banking/industry companies in Canada and banks in other countries 
 (USA, Australia, etc)
- Terrible Politics in the organization

headline: Just avoid Scotiabank if you can.
pros:
-You get 3 weeks paid vacation
-The medical benefits are pretty good.
cons:
I'm going to make this as objective as possible. I'm not sure what aspect of this job is the worst but overall, it's pretty terrible from top to bottom. The salaries are so low it's pathetic. The recruiter that hired me was gracious enough to start my wage at 19.74/h and after a year of employment, I got a raise of 7 cents per hour. It isn't just customer service reps that don't get paid well, it's everybody underneath directors. When I say everybody, I mean literally everybody. Analysts clear a little under $1500 bi-weekly, HR recruiters make roughly 60-63k/year and that's an entry level position that commands years of experience and a high level of education to get into. For reference, the person that hired me has a masters degree in HR, has almost 4 years of recruiting experience and makes 60,995/year. Any HR position available in the government, big pharma, or the tech industry pays a 60% premium on these roles. Unless you get into IT at Scotia, just don't bother. The wages are terrible.

Getting promoted is exceedingly difficult. If you're unlucky enough to get hired in the contact centre, management will move you around, keep your wage the same and give you more responsibility. 

This phrase is said so often it's just a cliché but it's true: "it's not what you know it's who you know". The end game is extracting the most amount of work from people while keeping the costs as low as possible. Scotiabank is the Nike factory of banks. Customer service, revolving credit, consultant roles (essentially supervisors), loans department and collections are all outsourced roles spread across Colombia, Mexico, and the Dominican Republic. 

Management...I don't even seriously know where to start. There are roughly 9 managers on the floor at the campus I work out of and 2 of them are good, helpful people. The rest micromanage their teams to the point where staff is just discouraged and have crippled morale. How many times per week can a person be spoken to about how many literal seconds they were in aftercall work prior to taking their break? 

This is the reality of working at scotiabank in the capacity I work in as a customer service rep; right now, I'm supposed to be working but I called in sick. I hate everything about my job. I don't have a single colleague that likes their job here, and I've only spoken to one person that is satisfied in their current role who also coincidentally told me that "it's not what you know, it's who you know". I had the pleasure of speaking to him while I was reversing an NSF fee he was charged. If you can avoid Scotia, then do so. Actually, if you can avoid working any entry level position in any bank, then avoid it. They're all trash. When I say "entry level" I mean anything from business analyst, HR recruiter, but ESPECIALLY customer service.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Classical bank, with some modernization already going on
pros:
- soft tickets, lots of free time to do courses
- good managers, they listen and advice to you on career choices
- No blame culture, retrosprective meetings with lots of chances to speak up your concerns
- good salary, over the average in Colombia
- writing this review during worktime.
cons:
- They have lots of automation tools, but still story mapping and requirements process are VERY POOR, building new features is a pain, BAs are not fully aware of their duties so you have to define features in the middle of a sprint. Could be just my project tho, but still bad.

- There's no motivation for going extra mile, managers prefer that you complete tickets before deadline and no more, also very tricky to finish on time poorly defined features you never now when you are really done.

- I am in a project with react front-end that is like the old west, everyone shoots on sight and we have similar modules with very different implementations for the same things so feels like there's no standard at all.

- The poor analysis also derives in a poor assignment of tickets when several people end up working in the same feature.

- Before start coding you have to ask several questions for tickets because there are no detail at all, and BAs just share links to another tickets instead of provide the info and thats for bug-tickets, for features it's even worse.

headline: Advisor keeps the lights on but are treated like company can run without the
pros: Big company not going bankrupt anytime soon. Literally nothing other than this if you work in branch world.
cons:
- you stop getting paid at 5pm but you can’t actually leave at 5pm.
- company does not make you feel important, everything is based on you doing maximum amount of sales but systems, other departments, management, will all work against you and tie down your efficiency.
- huge expectation for you to waste time selling Insurance and using sales tools that you don’t need to hit sales targets. But company will force you to waste these times on tools because they are petrified of lawsuits.
- heavy focus on women in leadership and not qualified candidates in leadership so most of branch management absolutely horrendous/can’t make a decision because lack of brain power.
- very very cheap in terms of what they buy for employees, how they celebrate employees, branch doesn’t buy food or keep the fridge stocked, nada.

headline: Contact Centre Job: try contacting another company for which to apply
pros: Can work from home. Good benefits.
cons:
Low pay. Took a 10k pay cut from my last job which was less demanding. Calls are none stop. Advancement to higher roles does not increase pay. Software for doing job is slow, error prone, makes job difficult, and since call time factored into your merger bonus, you are punished for poorly functioning applications. You are expected to reference dozens of resources that are shared on multiple different platforms and are given no time to review or organize them. Customers are always angery, which seems to be by design. Seemingly arbitrary changes to customer's services in order to change them more in fees result in demands for refunds which I suspect is the desired outcome in order to offer more products and services. I could go on but what's the point this job stinks.

I feel spoiled because I actually had a good job before covid. Way too many lifers at this job who are clueless to how overworked and underpaid they are. Actively looking for something else and will quit with zero regrets.

headline: Too many cooks in the kitchen
pros: Big budgets and stable work
cons:
Major changes on the digital marketing side didn't sit well with a lot of people. Changes were not properly communicated and resulted in many people leaving. The organization is very top-heavy which means that there is very little upward movement and things move so slow! Highly inefficient processes that deflate any motivation or creativity you may have.

90% of the senior manager don't have a clue about digital marketing which means the majority of your time is spent teaching instead of doing your best work.

headline: Good if you want to be in the financial industry
pros: The benefits are good as an entry level position and the pay is okay (especially if you make bonus)
cons: Everyone says they want to support/help you, but in reality they’re likely talking behind your back about how incompetent you are. The job itself is stressful and you deal with a lot of abusive customers. There’s high expectation to do extremely well, you’re surveys need to be 9s or 10s otherwise you’ll likely be scolded by your manager. I feel sick from anxiety on a daily basis from this job, but likely I’m just not a good fit for it. Good starting position for business/economic students maybe, or those looking to work in finance, but wouldnt recommend this job in the long term to anyone else. Oh, also very nitpicky about adherence; I got scolded for taking time to send of emails on behalf of customers because we should be writing them while we’re on the phones with customers and then instantly going to the next call (?) yeah, no. Also a lot of information to take in at once if you’re not familiar with finances, and can be difficult to keep up with updates. Systems are usually broken, and communication is garbage between employees, management, branch employees and customers. Very frustrating/anxiety inducing environment to work in.

headline: Great Company however poor morale with some individuals that work here!
pros: Great colleagues, profit sharing, benefits, vacation, sick, and personal days are offered.
cons: Lower than average pay, lots of work built into your day. Expected to know everything or to figure things out in a time crunch, little training done for very complex tasks. Learning isn't a problem but there's not enough time in the day to do so, and you'd have to stay behind if you want to learn with obviously no pay. Sometimes your managers can make or break your career - there can be very condescending and micromanaging individuals you'll come across during your time but turnover is high so you end up moving on. Beware of the sales practice of this bank, they tell you that they care about the clients but when push comes to shove you have to put the banks needs before doing what's best for your clients. Also some managers you end up working with are childish, doesn't take long to notice these groups of people.

headline: Hit impossible countless targets at all times, or be threatened with deductions on bonus and raise
pros: Good benefits, plenty of paid time off, always opportunity to advance
cons: As far as a sales job goes, Low pay for extremely demanding work, I currently have the same sales goals as another advisor who gets paid over 25% more per year than I do, CONSTANT pressure to meet FAR TOO MANY targets, everyone works through lunch and stays late/comes in early, overtime is not an option (don't even ask, they will laugh at you). Overall, you literally cannot do the job in the 37.5 hours you are scheduled, and you are simply expected to eliminate your work life balance to ensure that you can meet your goals.

headline: Dependable and customer centric job
pros: A stable job where you can actually make a difference to your client’s life. Your job also improves your financial knowledge not just for the job, but for your own life as well. The job is well-respected in the community too. Perks are nice. Good work-life balance.
cons: Slow pace of growth. Glass ceiling for financial growth is quite low. The job pays just enough to take care of your expenses in a smaller city. The pay doesn’t commensurate the breadth and width of responsibilities that you are expected to perform everyday. Many things which are beyond your control, such as market crash, economy tanking, unstable interest rates etc, can have a direct impact on your clients which brings a lot of stress. Your advice can make or break a family’s financial well being. So the weight of moral responsibility is also quite heavy.

headline: Awesome team, terrible tech and an aging philosophy
pros:
-great team attitude
-share owner program and pension plan is excellent
-great benefits
-mediocre training
-great company to start with and learn industry
cons:
-awful technology, no mobile computing platform or way to connect with customers using video conferencing
-no loan underwriting experience, and low limits for loans 
-terrible business strategy - advice driven but implementation of long term strategy is impacting the day to day and adding additional work for advisors, with reduced meeting times and working hours
-redundant micro management techniques
-work under branch management - manager was an advisor 20 years ago and literally had no idea how the current system worked - the better business FI are run by business banking professionals and not branch management and district leaders who don’t have an appropriate background for business banking
-stress you out even when you’re hitting your targets
-i saw someone go from a CR to a wealth trust in 6 m/o because a DVP liked them, career advancement is not guaranteed
-tons of redundancies in the process, very inefficient

headline: Stressful
pros: Awesome health benefits, good infrastructure, good community spirit at the branches I've worked at.
cons: Sales goals are constantly pushed nonstop and if you dont hit you target for one week expect your boss to be in your office on monday discussing that with you. Its a good line of work for people who are good at sales, but the whole "putting customers first" isn't entirely true because goals are the main (and sometimes feels like only) concern. You arent there to advise and help you are there to sell or build rapport so you can sell in the future. This is a salesman position in a pretty wrap.

headline: Customer Representative (CR)
pros: Fairly simple day to day tasks, lots of opportunity to grow especially if you are interested in the sales aspect of the job, and managers are willing to help if there is ever a concern/complaint.
cons: As a customer representative you have to remember you represent Scotiabank as a whole and your work affects the lives of everyday individuals. With that, one needs to be more careful in verifying customers in cases of fraud, or account takeovers as they are more of a threat than most people believe. Due to this possibility of fraud, there is a greater responsibility on the customer representative which I believe needs to be recognized more. More needs to be done for those Scotia employees and possibly even better communication between various departments as well.

headline: Not the best place to work
pros: Benefits are ok. However, they don’t cover every provider. They wouldn’t cover my regular checkup at the optometrist for some reason and I was then out $200.
cons: Low pay for the market. Gender inequality-Found out that many of the women get paid less than men for the same positions (Found out a much younger guy with no experience at all makes $7000 more a year than me). High stress-deal with a lot of complaints/maintenance, a ton of pressure to get sales, “good” clients are often given to higher advisors making it difficult for new advisors to reach goals, the way to achieve goals is not balanced based on how much work you do, but how much money the client has (for example, one advisor may have one client with $200,000 to invest and they meet their goal for 2 weeks while another advisor gets 25 clients with only $100 to invest but they don’t even reach their goal for one week). The amount of effort is very uneven. The low pay and meetings that make you feel bad in front of everyone if you don’t meet your weekly goal are demoralizing and doesn’t make you want to do more. Best to look for a job that pays at market for the same work. Training is non existent. It’s all about talking to clients and making them happy, nothing about how to actually do the job and process paperwork. Other advisors often steal your sales, but management ignores this. Often expected to bend over backwards and give up our lunch/breaks to get sales.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros:
The work environment is diverse, with a well mixed culture, the product line up is simple and they reward well for good performance. They have invested a lot into their technology which helps to make the job a lot easier. There are many volunteer opportunities and career training. Having the right manager will make the job even better. 

- Inclusive 
- fast paced 
- competitive pay 
- learning opportunities
cons: It is a large, international organization and feels that way as you are working there. Because of the amount of people that work there and want to work there you will be nothing but a number. Your managers may care about your career progression but the organization as a whole does not. And that is revealed in how they promote financial advisors. A lot of politics and numbers. They have systems in place that will prevent you from being promoted even if you hit your numbers and your management wants to promote you. If you want to advance in your career at a decent rate, Scotiabank is NOT the place to be. Many MANY great Financial Advisors have left because of this. I was employed by them for 6 years and seen many leave due to how they treat career advancement. I did 140% of my own targets for 9 straight months, did well with compliance AND was a leader in my branch, having won best of the best in the last quarter and went it came time to promote me they came up with some dumb excuse! I quit the same day and have never looked back. You’ll enjoy it, just don’t expect to move up, that would take a miracle.

headline: Worst company for your retirement only if you have no other choice
pros:
There is nothing much good about this place that I can think of. One thing "good" maybe this is the most "relaxing" place where you are free not to work as hard as you normally would. But for a dedicated professional like myself, I am not sure if I should treat this as a "pro".

 Once you are in, you want to run. If you just come out of college looking for new job, go elsewhere.
cons:
- People are like ignorant school boys and don't know what they are doing. The lack of knowledge about their fields is simply appalling.
- People simply slack in their work. Bunch of lazy folks chitchatting who do not have any motivation to work for a broken company. People came late and left office at 3-4pm. At 5pm the office is pretty much 80% empty, which is just unheard of!
- Abuse of work-from-home (before COVID-19) as a way to hide from their work and responsibilities.
- Management is a joke and totally incompetent. They don't know how to manage people. Sometimes you think you could be a better manager yourself. They don't reward your merits for sure and fire people when they get angered at your good suggestions. In fact, they all need to get fired.
- Strong smell of discriminatory practices against certain people and races.
- Pay is utterly horrible and unforgivable as compared to other competitors.
- It's a retirement home when you have no one else hiring you and you are already in your 50's having no other choices to make your ends meet.
- Bad everything. Do not work there. It was my total regret to have joined the company years ago in the first place. I got a much much better job since then!

headline: Worst work experience ever
pros: Probably the only positive aspect I have experienced is their benefits plan, and maybe the location if you live downtown.
cons: Management is pure chaos. People are pushed to management positions because they don´t know what they are doing, so the VP pushes them out of their own team, often giving them a promotion in another one. Accountability is 0. Communication is 0. Cockiness is 1000. The W3 Project is the worst team I have ever seen in my entire life. They look down on anybody who is not on their same level, they don´t even say hello when crossing paths. 90% of them don´t know what they are doing, nor have previous experience, but they think they know it all. Very arrogant. The constantly lie to their employees at every meeting, and during the hiring process. Nothing has changed in almost 2 years. The incompetency of management is stellar, which completely impairs your professional development among other things.

headline: Global Reg Compliance Technology - Unless you're Cantonese, forget it.
pros: - brand name on the CV
cons:
- unless you speak cantonese and part of the 'in' crowd you won't get anywhere (trust me I'm part Asian)
- ALL the senior management in GRCT are Cantonese...no diversity at all
- One of the Directors picks up girls from clubs and hires them even though they are not remotely able to perform the job required
- GRCT is all about showcases and PR - they don't care about the actual IT technology. If you create a spreadsheet with a few formulas, they will label it an automation tool and present it to a showcase saying they solved the business problems by 'automating' sth...
- A lot of bullying from Management and favouritism overall
- External hiring is rigged by referrals/personal friends who aren't qualified for the role
- expect your business stakeholders to hate you due to the bad rep of GRCT
- no transparency - they will promise you X and then pretend they never did and say you asked for Y, not X.
- demand you work extra hours for no additional pay or compensation - all to serve as part of their Technology showcases

headline: Scorecard? You mean lottery card?
pros:
- It's a well-known company
- Nice to have a big brand to grow with
cons:
- Management don't care about your growth
- You're expected to start achieving goals right away, and regardless they will place you on a performance plan. Ridiculous pressure.
- The top-down expectation is to achieve targets, and if you're just starting out, the ways you can "score" on your scorecard are few and far between

headline: Terrible
pros: Good benefits, good pay, training available online
cons: I have never seen a company which followed the Peter principle of people being promoted to their max level of incompetence as much as I did in this company. My boss hired me based on my strengths and then refused to let me use them in any way. Then she continulusly audited my work for small errors like capitalization and font and brought them up in weekly coaching meetings. Coaching meets for her were session in which she formalized small issues that she messaged to me in skype during the week and then ended with "tell me how i can coach you". Like it was my job to coach her how to coach me. She lacked both technical skill and legal knowledge and was vastly under qualified for her job, and it was obvious the only reason why was in her position was because she has family ties to the bank.

headline: ok
pros: The compensation structure is decent. If you are good at cold calling or closing business then you will make a lot of money.
cons:
You get no referrals from anyone at Scotia. The branch will send you nothing nor will other partners. 
You get no exposure to other partners or areas of the bank.
You get no office of your own at the branch.
You're basically building your book from the ground up starting with 0 assigned clients to you. 
Different parts of the bank don't work together. There is no collusion with other departments to give a single great experience for a client. 
You can only sell Dynamic or Scotia funds
Scotia computer systems are garbage

headline: Excessive work load
pros: customer relationships, helping them buy a house, save for a trip, buy a car, save for retirement.
cons: Favouritism,  Management passing their client's work to staff with an already excessive work load.  Staff are told they have poor time management skills when they try to get relief from their supervisor.  Power struggles between the managers/supervisors of different departments.  Blatant prejudice against gays, lesbians, & obese ppl.  Cruelty towards staff on short, or long term disability not discouraged, & often displayed by Managers.   Management breeds an environment of competition, rarely teamwork.  Customer's importance is based on their portfolio of products/dollar amounts vs long term loyalty.   Staff Loyalty not valued.

headline: The people are great but the company isn't
pros:
- Great leadership in most departments
- Free coffee
- Development plans
- A lot of internal movement and room for growth
cons:
- Mainly hires 'Casual' positions which do not include any benefits or vacations.
- Salaries are based on on 'Level system' which is common for banks but the system is completely unbalanced  which result in very non-competitive salaries for most positions.
- As mush as there is room to grow, there is also a lot of employee turn-over due to the lack of job security (Casual positions) and non-competitive salaries.
- It can take years before going from Casual to Full-time permanent which only then allows you to obtain benefits, vacations and job security.
- Upper management (VP's, Directors) tend to give the illusion of willingness to improve upon these cons but fail to deliver.
- Only provided 2 weeks vacation when full-time.

headline: Many teams, many different cultures
pros: - Nothing that other banks do not provide
cons:
Overall Scotiabank Cons:
- Constant risk of budget cuts
- They have a hard time understanding the concept of meritocracy so the place has many entitled childre of top management (with the odd exception)

About the team I worked in
- Toxic environment
- *Always* short-staffed
- Lack of regard over people's feelings: I once heard the boss mock the fact that someone took a day off to go to an aunt's funeral, dismissing it as a dumb way to use a day off - in front of the whole team (including the person that took the day off)
- Total disregard for basic ethics: One of the directors asked his team to make sure not to give him a bad review of management (it was supposed to be anonymous) because that would translate into lower bonuses for everyone in his team.
- I could go on but you get the point..

Also too many meetings and bureaucracy, meetings about meetings, annoying fake corporate "coaching" with managers. Just stop abusing us with meetings and let us do the work.

headline: Nice but disorganized
pros:
Scotiabank is a huge organization, so this varies a lot depending on the division/area, this review is for Scotiabank International Banking division based in Toronto:
- In general, good work/life balance.
- Good work environment, colleagues are friendly.
cons:
- Chaotic: multi million dollar projects and priorities can change suddenly not due to market conditions but due to politics or disorganization of senior executives.
- Mediocre bonus compensation.

headline: Scotiabank - Digital Factory - Developers' nightmare
pros: Nice people, some of the projects are pretty cool.
cons:
Digital Factory initially started and was advertised as a fancy workspace in order to attract IT talent. It was nice for a few years or so, but not anymore.

- They completely ran out of the office space. Heard the CEO talking about 350 people at Digital Factory on TV? That's how it was designed to be. And now double that number. There's 2 categories of people - those who joined DF early and claimed their seats/desks and new joiners who don't have that "luxury". You would think that having a desk and at least one extra screen for a developer (or any role, really) is the least employers can do, but none of the new joiners get that. If you join now you will end up working from a cafeteria or just sitting in the hallway with a laptop on your knees hurting your back while being surrounded by a bunch of people as if you are sitting in the middle of the St. Lawrence market on Sunday. To be fair if you work there long enough to see somebody from your team leave - you can try to claim "dead man's" seat. Nice, eh.
- Very noisy environment. Which is caused by the overpopulation of the space. It's impossible to book a meeting room and people are forced to have "meetings" right at their desks.
- They completely banned GitHub in the whole bank not realizing that the world runs on the back of the Open Source software. If you actively deal with Open Source tech - try to code for a day without being able even to browse GitHub and see how it goes for you. But then the management said that we had to compete with the Big Tech who's running full speed into the banking space. See the problem here?
- Their food is some cheap processed junk 50% of the time. Digital Factory is located quite far from the downtown core and there is no food courts around to buy food from. They have their own cafeteria that feeds you with a bunch of carbs at a discount. You'll have to cook unless you want to eat that.

headline: My Time at Scotia
pros: Scotia offers great employee flex-benefits, esop, great social assistance. I was lucky to work at a branch with a fun work environment and made friends with my co-workers. Starting out as a CSR was a really good opportunity that taught me a lot of essential skills. In addition, the company would be more than happy to help you climb the ladder if you show interest.
cons: The new management system they had around the time I left was very frustrating. The work schedules were very unfavourable. You’d work weird hours like 11-2pm sometimes or 1-5pm.  So it’s hard to get another part time job as the work hours are awkward. It’s also hard to get more work hours as that’s one of the company’s focus on cutting. They try to run lean on staff and it can be really stressful if you’re working at a busy branch. Due to those reasons and more, there’s always a high turnover. Then again it’s more of an entry level temp job.

headline: Great place to work - Still up and coming
pros:
- Welcoming and filled with driven, smart and motivated people.
- Looking to make big positive jumps in organizational culture and digital.
- The Bank is going through a revamp of sorts in multiple segments and looking to become more innovative, diverse, and forward looking. The progress has been good so far.
- Scotiabank's ability to inspire internal networking, provide opportunities, and empower individuals reach their potential is very well developed.
cons:
- Scotiabank still have a reputation as a bank that tends to follow (RBC and TD) rather than take initiative/risks and lead. It will take some work to shed this reputation.
- While there is a good level of ethnic and gender diversity in the director and VP level, higher up executive levels still require more diversity in their make-up.
- There is a sentiment among workers that the Bank could do better to offer more competitive compensation to its workers.

headline: Lots of easy work but no technical growth or direction by senior management
pros:
1. Easy work, you wont be stressing your ML/AI/python skills
2. Opportunity to grow as a manager and learn about banking
3. there is lots of data here
4. great opprotunity to network among other data scientist within the bank and in Toronto area
cons:
No technical direction 
examples: 
1. in less than 5 years,  SVP position has changed 3 times, reorg happens every 8-12 months
2. the bank is hella confused on tech stack.  we've been switching priorities between on prem and cloud (the usual providers) for a long time, and no one really cares what  happens 
2. projects are too simple, you won't gain any technical skills
3. most data scientist are not part of an P&L business line therefore whatever you work on will probably never be productionized or used by anyone. ie mostly for show
3. they block github, and don't give the necessary tools to do our work (slack, VMs, gpus, python3, external apis/tools, dual monitors, decent coffee machine)
4. security and privacy is slow, leadership is old and doesn't understand the needs of a younger customer base and a younger workforce
5. pay is too low, salary adjustments are 1/2 of  inflation, hr doesn't understand that our roles are very high in demand, so we have a lot of attrition
6. old tech stacks are being used still, there is no clear direction to upgrade or migrate to 21st century tools.  The bank has too many employees (like 80k-100K) and too many divisions, to even consider an overall tech revamp/implementation
7. its slow, its a bank what'd you expect, but its nice that the slowness can allow a lot reflection time and personal+independent development 
8. Scotia does not care about the environment, we still use plastic dipped coffee cups and waste tons of paper
9. no career growth for a technical role unless you are willing to switch to a management role (director/vp)

headline: Toxic culture in GBM as far as the eye can see
pros: None that stand out from other firms in the space any more. With the high turnover, there's a good chance you'll progress through the ranks faster.
cons:
Scotiabank GBM used to be a great place to work. Everybody pulled together in common cause. In the last five years, multiple shifts in management, as well as a drive to lower costs everywhere have created a toxic stew of too much work needed too quickly with not enough people or money to do it.  Management seeks to cut costs by clawing back bonuses, benefits, pensions, and everything - rather than reporting a loss for a quarter or two and fixing the systemic problems that abound everywhere.  

The result is a very high turnover rate, with many staff teetering on full burn-out - and NOBODY enjoys their jobs anymore.  The expectation is work yourself to death for a compensation package that is higher anywhere else on the street, and an environment filled with backstabbers, cliques, and pettiness.  The days of BNS being a great place to work is long dead.  Brian and Co. killed it - and for practically no benefit.

Complete training programs at dedicated training school.
Offers low rate loans and credit cards @3.5% p.a. (after 2 years service).
cons:
Lack of transparency as to direction of the organization.
A lot of persons  have resigned over the past 6 months and the bank is not doing enough to replace the staff which leads to the remaining staff being overworked.
Still practices favoritism which is highly evident in a lot of sectors.
Adaptation of 1st world digital at too much of a rapid rate leaves senior citizens out in the cold.

headline: Negative  Work Culture
pros: Base pay and bonus pay are strong, the hours are generally fair and Small Business Advisors have the flexibility to work outside of the office visiting customers and prospect at their place of business.
cons:
There is an incredible amount of back end work sales staff have to complete while managing phone call and meeting goals and preparing numerous tracking reports. 

People are just a number, the company rides advisors until they break and replace them without hesitation. 

Culture is very negative with managers and advisors throwing one another under the bus, advisors working to steal clients from one another and constant buck-passing.

 "Cover your backside" and "it is what it is" are slogans of the workplace. 

It is very challenging to succeed in an environment where you have no support or coaching and are kept in constant fear of losing your job.

headline: 145 King street customer service circle  Worst place to work
pros: work life balance, good place to grow.
cons: I was excited to join Scotiabank as CSR, looking forward to grow within the company. Unfortunately I left the job after two months of verbal harassment from the so called "team leaders", who do not know what they are doing and utterly impatient.  During my training they were not helpful at all, they talked down on you when you do something wrong and never really explains to you when you ask them questions. I was yelled at in front of other colleagues when I made a mistake, I have never cried at any other work, but I did in this place.  I couldn't do well even if I wanted to, in a such an uncivilized environment. I wouldn't recommend this location to anyone, my friend works for Scotia itself in a smaller branch, and she loves it. I guess it all depends on your work team.

headline: 5+ Years as a Branch Employee
pros: Great place to gain experience in all areas of the business environment (finance, HR, marketing, accounting). Lots of connections and lots of opportunity for lateral and upwards movement. A fun company culture. Generous bonuses do exist for those who go above and beyond.
cons: The branch-level compensation is insufficient for the workload and responsibility. Low level employees/management are often expected to provide a level of service to the customers that is barely possible with the support and resources given by upper management. The big banks are still segregated into many different departments; each with different functions, and this can create an inefficient workflow process, poor communication, and a bad experience for both employees and customers.

headline: Success as an Advisor

- My branch environment was excellent. Lots of great people.

cons:
- numbers, numbers, numbers. If you dont have your numbers, you're no good to the company. 
- management in branches has poor leadership skills. People get bumped up very easily and they may not be a good fit for that particular role.
- advisor support lines are ridiculously slow. You have to be passed around to get to where you need to be
 
This role consists of constant emails and voicemails. Clients always come first. They dont care if you're on vacation or sick. They need their job done. So, if you're looking for a role like this, be prepared for that!

headline: Great for immigrants, but with low pay and complex structure
pros:
The bank is great for newcomers as it has a large footprint outside of Canada and thus favors language skills (Spanish in particular). Also being one of the worst paying banks, it's easier to hire qualified immigrants (but with no Canadian experience) since it's tough (money wise) to steal from the competitors.

Benefits are good - 4 weeks of vacation for level 8, 3 personal days, 5 sick days, an okay insurance coverage.

Good work/life balance, most people work from 8:30 to 5 pm and are not expected to work after hours. From level 9 (director) up things are slightly different.

Lots of women in leadership position
cons:
Scotia is massive with lots of different areas. Expect to encounter different cultures within different areas of the bank. Lots of gossip, and unfortunately some senior management incentivise that, by asking around people's opinions on their peers!

Pace is slow, very slow. Overall the bank is very risk avoider, so decision making is hard and lengthy.

Progressing in the career is also though. Ambition is not really expected and though there are tons of jobs posted daily, applying online doesn't really get you anywhere, so you need to do a lot of networking and get a direct referral / introduction to the job poster.  

Pay is worse than other banks. Base bonus for level 8 is 12% (the actual can be more dependent on performance).

System is very bad, contra-productive. Management is not competent, a lot of discrepancy between different managers and lack of communication.

headline: People abusing work from home
pros: Ridiculously low pressure environment.  People come in late and go early.
cons: I would say quite some people are "abusing" work from home here since it is allowed and no upper management cares, and they definitely take it too far.  Most of the time they don't have a valid reason for doing so.   It's not like they have a doctor's appointment or anything they need to take care at home.  They make it a routine to take 2 to 3 days work from home every week.  That's quite outrageous and their boss won't care.   Worst thing is it's very clear they are doing much less on those days.  It's their paid time offs and you just know it.  This is very demoralizing for those working in office.

headline: Generous salaries and benefits
pros: Smart people, professional atmosphere as you would expect from a multinational bank, managers care about employee growth, access to mentors, clean offices, managers don't have an "I'm better then you" attitude that many other companies have.  Big focus on ethics and respect for your coworkers.  You won't find any unprofessional behavior here and if you do those who are acting disrespectfully are fired.  Managers sit next to employees and aren't on a power trip. Great place to start a career as there are many smart and professional people who care about your growth and success both inside the company and your own professional development.  Very mature business processes and exposure to how a leading company does things.  Processes are very mature and optimized.
cons:
Open concept workplace so makes it hard to really feel like you have your own cubicle where you can personalize and make it feel more like home.  The office I worked from was very sterile meaning it was very corporate and lacked any type of character.  You have a very small and basic lunch area, no free snacks offered even on fridays, basic tea/coffee/refrigerator set up.  The open concept takes time getting used to as you have no privacy and when people are on calls you can hear everything.  Meeting rooms also have no privacy they are pure glass.

A little more flexibility to work from home would be nice especially because of the lower Manhattan location is hard to get to unless you live in immediate New York City area. 

The bank has HQ in Toronto so hiring and onboarding is extremely slow for U.S. employees.  Can take a few weeks just to receive laptop, monitors, phone, etc.  In the meantime you have to try to stay busy and not looking bored.

headline: Alright company but far from perfect...
pros:
Salaries are decent
Customer interactions are usually very positive
Coworkers are usually very nice and respectful
cons:
Benefits and Employee Share programs are a joke. If you aren't working full time hours, you won't have access to any medical benefits or anything else worth while. Usually when you first start working there you are put on as casual which means they don't have to put you on the schedule if they don't want. It's frustrating.
A LOT of micro-management within all departments.
Supervisors and managers don't always have proper training when it comes to policies and other important areas. They can be very unapproachable and unprofessional.
If you have questions or concerns for the HR department, they will take the time to hear you out but won't give you options and will pretty much tell you to get over it.
If you think seniority means anything to this company, you're wrong. They treat their customers better than their employees.

fair balance between work and life

cons:
it passed its best time for employees due to management change in the past 5 years, it was good 5 or 10 years ago though salary has been one of the lowest in the banks in toronto.

top management (CEO/EVP) are focusing on their performance KPI and showcase their vision on "change" but not sure how effective and feasible it is

the mid-level management (SVP, VP, Directors) are occupied by a lot of people who seems not knowing what they are doing, could be partly caused by inefficiency from top management. 

it has a lot of confusion and ambiguities for first-line managers (sr. manager, manger etc.) and need to bear/absorb a lot of frustration unless you are really lucky.

headline: Not Worth Your Time
pros: Working at Scotiabank looks good on your resume and gives you valuable experience in law and finance.
cons: Don't waste more than two years at this place. Upper management treats all employees as unnecessary liabilities. New hires from other institutions will be paid $3,000-$5,000 more per year than existing employees with more experience. Salaries are stagnant and inadequate, most senior financial advisors with 20+ years at Scotiabank earn $51,000 to $60,000 per year and management will always try to rip you off. Employees, as well as managers, always seem to disappear without a reason. Moral is always low and nobody enjoys working here.Internal computer systems fail on a daily basis. If you watch insider trading reports you'll notice that Brian Porter has been cashing out lately...I strongly suggest you do the same!

Not a good environment if you want to challenge the status quo or get things done quickly. Internal politics creates highly dysfunctional operating structure.

I'm the living proof that as long as you are highly knowledgeable with what you do and you have good communication skills, meaning good in oral and written english, people will love you. :)
cons: Scotiabank keeps hiring people who lacks proper english communication skills. I often get clients complaining to me about their experience with a different financial advisor because of their poor communication skills.

headline: Manager
My worst job experience
pros: Probably the only thing I can think is there are very good few professionals that really want to make a change. However there is a huge lack of empowerment.
cons: Where to start? I was hire with very high expectations about my role, upper management said to me that their objective was to change how HR was helping our employees and how important it was the change. Since I joined I saw a terrible lack of empowerment at every level, people just don’t take decisions because they are afraid of having not support. The IT tools inside are way to old and complicated, I was never able to have a cell phone that worked and I was a having a Director role, my onboarding was terrible and at the end they let me go because the project I was hired for did not happen at all due to a lack of planning and budget issues they did not plan. I can say for sure this is the worst experience in my 20 years of career.

headline: Performance Management at Scotiabank
pros: There will ALWAYS be tons of job postings at Scotiabank because of the high turnover and the toxic environment.
cons:
Scotiabank's performance management system has the following 3 steps:
1)   Tell the employee they are NOT meeting expectations but NOT give them any specific reasons why.
2)   Immediately, post the employees position in order to find a replacement.
3)  Once a replacement is found, fire the employee.
No-one in Canada who is mentally competent would want to work in such a toxic environment.

headline: Shareholders first
pros: There are some really great people in the organization.  I enjoyed working with the teams, helping clients succeed, and finding new ways to solve problems.
cons: I loved working here for a long time and was very loyal to the brand.  Felt in the first part of my career that customers and employees were important and respected.  Worked hard and was committed to the job as I believed in our organization and what we did.  Over the last few years saw behaviours of senior leadership deteriorate to the point that staff were openly chastised and humiliated in public settings.  Changes were thrust upon teams without engaging in the process.  Expectation was to tie the line and not make waves.  I used to be very proud to be a Scotiabanker for many years.  Feel very sad at what it became.

headline: Senior Credit Solutions Analyst
pros: Scotiabank has a strong HR culture, stable job, steady income. Lots of good people who want to make their clients better off.
cons: Pay feels below average. Technology infastructure is inefficient. Way too difficult to execute basic tasks or update information. Inherent advantages of customer trust and large deposits seem squandered due to a lack of willingness to adopt 21st century technologies to conduct business. People power is thrown at bad processes to solve 20th century problems when technology and new ways of doing business are ignored and not invested in.

Some bad sneaky people (former steven Harper staffers who are weak and terrible communicators but good at being sneaky, playing politics and back stab their bosses and peers).   --too many layers and weak people managers.  Unprofessional and wasteful. 
A good stock to short if they don't clean up the weak people and execute.  Quality over game playing should rule.

headline: The company that will never grow
pros: Benefits, vacation package, employee pricing
cons:
New CEO cannot care less for his people. All he cares about is profit, sales results and technology. Yet how is going to get all of that without quality people, he hasn’t figured out yet. I’m sure he will soon. He calls the bank a technology company. So go figure if you wanna work here. 
Managers from old boys club gotta go. There are plenty of them at Scotia. 
They keep promoting diversity and inclusion but in reality it’s all just words and lies that they are telling the public so they can fit in. 
Whoever was able to retire or quit - did the best thing to themselves. They always hiring so think twice before you apply.

headline: Small Business Advisor
pros: Loved the customers... truly miss them. Not many pros other then great customers that are getting ripped off with fees.
cons: Scotiabank pretends to care about the customer.... They only care about the bottom line. They treat staff like slaves and have pushed out most of the more experienced staff hiring young kids and call them advisors. I get better advice from my garbage man. They have taken away the work life balance and make advisors work 80% of the extended hours shifts. I left Scotia to go to a company that actually treats staff and customers amazing. They really need a new CEO and not one the snipes out all his competition and squeezes all employees to fatten up his wallet.

headline: Scotiabank in the U.S.: Chaotic organization
pros: Some good people, prime location in Manhattan.
cons: It all began with the departure of our former global CEO, Mr. Waugh.  The new management took the reigns and turned the place into a disorganized, chaotic organization.  People in executive leadership roles come and go, layoffs became a permanent state of life, wave after wave, including people who have devoted their lives to BNS and spent 20-30 years there(!).  Changing priorities.  Favoritism.  To make a career there, you need to learn navigate the "underground" currents and be on time to dump those managers who are no longer in favor, and befriend those who are still standing strong. Very sad... The pay is WAY below competition, trust me!  In fact, employees leave on their own and ... head to competitors.  Scotiabank used to be a solid, respectable bank on the Street.  Not any longer.  If you are considering employment - go elsewhere.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros:
Workperks
Employee share plan
Staff account and credit cards
cons:
Where do I begin? 

1. Lack of training required to do your work as expected by management. 3 months of training which mostly involves role play calls and little experience doing the actual work. When I asked if I could shadow someone on the job to learn the process I was told that I should know how to do it and if not, to go back and read the Job Aids (it's like reading a dictionary). 

2. Promotions have nothing to do with merit or performance. I was told by interviewers when applying for a promotion that there is a lot to consider when hiring someone, particularly the number of men and women in branch so they will look for who fits in the branch at that time. 

3. Be ready for a zero accountability workplace. Tasks will be reassigned and passed through multiple hands before reaching someone who will finally action it. No one is willing to take the responsibility of requests and will hand it off at any given opportunity. 

4. If you have a concern, keep it to yourself. The human resources department is only there for show. They will listen to your concern regardless of the validity and take no action to improve your situation. My religion was openly mocked in front of my colleagues. When I raised this concern with the department, after an "extensive investigation" they said it was a "harmless joke" and that was the end of it. In fact, they were asking me what I did to make him say something like that. 

5. Very high turnover. The gist of it is that you are expendable.

All about making connections to avoid being the next in line to be axed.

headline: Vancouver Main Branch specifically
pros:
-Other Tellers and Financial Advisors were excellent at collaborating, very professional, and nice to work with. Mostly a younger workplace.

-Easy to develop a friendly relationship with clients and partners who regularly come in.

-Good benefits/vacay for young full timers or 5-day-a-week part timers  just starting out.

-Convenient downtown location.
cons:
-Training was very disorganized and rushed, and they expect you to be proficient with the job in mere weeks despite the amount of industry/process knowledge and system familiarity needed.

-Supervisors were at times extremely rude, disrespectful, micromanaging, or not at all supportive. Supervisors would sometimes openly berate and reprimand employees for minor mistakes, or for even asking questions or expressing the need of support. Supervisors will also get upset with you if you don't take your breaks at the strictly allotted times but also question you if you use the bathroom more than they think is necessary (which is absurd and humiliating).

-Management was totally oblivious or unresponsive to the level of disorganization in training/onboarding new employees, and the unprofessional behaviour of their supervisors. 

-You'll be hired as a part timer just under the full time threshold and pay you like a part timer, but in reality you will work full time hours due to late after hour closing procedures.

-Extremely high turnover and low service staff morale due to poor supervisor/management leadership and support, low pay-high stress, very little flexibility in working hours, and almost no autonomy.

headline: Below average
pros: Staff rate, staff accounts, great team work environment, opportunities to learn new things, some benefits, annual bonus
cons: Very little pay for such a high stress and high responsibility position. Lack of sufficient opportunities for career advancement. The department is almost always short-staffed which leads to a highly inconsistent lunch schedule and a total lack of breaks.  Highly stressful training process, which felt more like a survival of the fittest challenge. Very outdated technology and problematic communication between branches makes the job even harder.  Expected to work full time hours for a part time compensation and benefits. The workload has been gradually increasing, while many positions were eliminated.

headline: Retail banking advisor life
pros:
-Great benefits, not all banks the same. They do attempt to reevaluate their paying schene to try and match market salaries.
-People you work with are great, everyone that is non-management gets a long like a team.
cons:
-Culture: They have a morning huddle thing in retail banking. I believe the original purpose was to promote team support and individual skill, now the whole purpose is to bash on you and tell you how underperformed you are  if you didn't reach your daily/weekly goal. 
-Performance: Hardworking does not matter, only sales results do. Even if you met with many clients to help them, if you didn't sell, anything then  you're considered underperforming.
-Admin work is beyond belief, you scan things 24/7.
-Culture: Over time is normal, you should not get paid for it either.

headline: FINANCIAL ADVISOR
pros:
1. Customers are great and (i know it sounds cliche but....) it feels good knowing you are helping them achieve their goals.

2.  Good benefits like health card, free banking, discount on iTrade

3.  Huge organizations so lots of potential for growth (If by some miracle you get called for a position you applied for online, usually promotions given to friends and favorites
cons:
1. Office gossiping is very high and the Managers sit and do nothing to help the sales team meet goal. The pressure is completely on you. 

2. Tremendous amount of paperwork and service issues that takes up the advisors time. Your whole day can get ruined with paperwork

3. Sales goals are ridiculous and stressful

4. Compensation is not worth the stress. FA4 $40k, FA5 $50k, FA6 $65k. Goals 12mil, 18mil, 26mil respectively for a medium size branch

5. High turnover (Maybe treat current staff properly and this will change). Also customers hate when their advisor changes often

6. When you leave work your mind will still be there (high stress environment)

headline: Wrong Way
pros: Coworkers are generally nice. Middle management are doing all they can to help.
cons:
Employees are treated as completely expendable.  You are just a cog in the machine now.  Sr Management thinks that they are doing YOU a favour by employing you.  If you are not a white male, you won't get ahead.  

Burn & churn is the new motto.

Sr & E Management are so out of touch on how the business lines actually perform job functions.  They have slashed so many "older" (aka expensive employees) without giving middle management enough time to implement cross-training, so there are huge gaps in basic functions & knowledge.  Everyone left has to scramble to figure it out.

Sr Mgmt also crams down initiatives that do not consider any current business processes, project management teams are completely clueless on how to bridge the new with old to transition.  

Basically, everything is a dumpster fire

headline: Great Benefits, great potential in employees & a management that needs improvement!
pros:
- Excellent Benefits (medical coverage...etc) that start on your 1st day working there. You don't have to wait for the 3 months probation to pass which is beyond amazing.
- Big company so there's a lot of position you can move up to.
- Great workplace and work environment
cons:
- Too much work politics, to move up you need to kiss the supervisor's behind or if they like you either way they will favour you and help you moving up the ladder.
- It's a big company so there's a lot of room for career growth. However, they need to update their policies. Why maintain a qualified individual to a position for 1 to 2 years just because say so. I saw people with lots of potential being stuck at the customer service level although they have the skills and education to go for a higher level position. 
- Micro management is obsolete. Controlling people pee breaks and things of that sort isn't how you increase your productivity and your profits. They're not robots!
- There was a lot of restructuring and people loosing their job at the time I was there. Especially at the management level.

headline: Once upon a time a great company
pros: Good co-workers and a very good product suite
cons: Absolutely terrible corporate culture. The focus is utterly on the numbers with no consideration of the human factor. The bank suddenly removed medical benefits for anyone retiring after 2021 so there's people who have worked there 20-30 years who were counting on that but wont get it.  If they have a preexisting condition they're out of lucky competely and even if they don't it's VERY expensive. There's tremendous pressure to hit targets and staff go to grey areas to hit them. if you're politically connected you get off, if not you get let go.  Also lots of unpaid overtime.

cons:
Many Sr Manager cadre is below par & poorly skilled, makes difficult to work professionally. 
No-one dress professionally or speaks professionally, so don't expect humble treatment. Beaurocracy can be experienced at its best at these levels
Poor perfromace and perfect politics is criteria for success, so if you concentrate more on performance more than politics you will be left behind. 
Often seen experienced leaders leaving like jumping from sinking ship, newbie executive obviously look disconnected, lost and nervous.
Management lives in one's own world, far from reality. No transparency in startegic view, often don't walk the talk.
Employee engagement is negative, lower level executive not connected to ground

headline: Bilingual Customer Service Representative
pros: Retirement, drug, dental, ESOP, life insurance, all pretty standard bank offerings.
cons: Entry-level job for which previous experience is not taken into consideration salary-wise; no office supplies provided; desk/chair/keyboard desinfectants rarely provided; job responsibilities do not match job description;  superficial training; broken-down chairs (7/15)  used in training room; on-the-phone training sessions conducted by rotating selected employees instead of  professional trainers. Position is heavily slanted towards sales; incomplete, scattered, disparate knowledge bases to rely on; insufficient or non-existent "consultants" (subject matter experts) & very evident age discrimination applied irrespective of how good your performance is over the years. Duplicitous hiring practices used to hire 15-20  of us  full time, part-time positions  then we were all fired 2-3 weeks before the end of probation.

headline: Like a football team managed by cheerleaders
pros: vacation time, mediocre but recently improved benefits plan. Salary is lower than industry standard, which makes it far below Canadian median.
cons:
Managers possess no leadership or coaching skills and are chosen purely based on tenure. They noisily suck up a half hour of every morning in front of a big game board reviewing what their sales team is doing or planning. Sales staff regularly fabricate leads because of the pressure to present something in these rallies, then sit in empty offices making phone calls the rest of the day. 

Managers openly gossip about absent or former employees with new and current staff, exposing personal and confidential topics related to employment records. I guess Scotia has not been sued in this area yet. They'll surely get around to correcting these confidentiality breaches after a lawsuit.

The system is filled with many unacknowledged glitches, which you need to sit through smiling like an imbecile while you try to call help desks that do not answer their phones! The only alternative is to excuse yourself and hope that you can find someone in the branch who’s figured out a workaround.

Rewards for movies and junk food are not competitive with what the big 4 banks are offering, and attract a lower demographic than is needed to provide the large amounts of  investment cash required by financial advisors to meet high sales targets.

Because managers have even lower knowledge of the systems than their staff and feel it's beneath them to provide coaching in this area, it’s not unusual for new advisors to spend one to four hours of unpaid overtime, sorting through pre-digital type paperwork and badly processed transactions.

headline: Stay away
pros: Not many come to mind, but if I had to pick something the benefits are alright.
cons: Management is out of touch, and don't seem to know how to actually manage.  New hires are tossed into branches with no training and are expected to be a burden on their colleagues while they fail at the customers expense.
