headline: Customer representative
pros: There is absolutely nothing great about working for Scotiabank
cons: I’ve been with Scotia Bank for 3 years now and at first I loved it. But as I got to understand the banks wants, I really hate it. I work over my minimum hours for the whole 3 years and now they want to give ALL staff the minimum hours offered. Scotiabank only cares about Scotiabank and not the employees. I was really hoping to improve my self and eventually work my way “up” to better job positions with Scotiabank... but now I think it’s better to find a financial institution that cares more about the staff. It’s unfortunate that the bank is changing for the worst. I’ve done extra courses to better my knowledge with the bank and I’ve previously spoke to management about what I can do to help myself “move up” and seeking advice to better myself. In the end they simply don’t care. They hiring new people off the street with no experience rather than move the employees they have up. Scotiabank is the worst please to work for. I highly suggest never to apply.

headline: Toxic and disheartening atmosphere, you are just a number and are disposable
pros:
- I've made some close friendships with coworkers
- Pay seems mostly fair
cons:
- due to intense pressure placed on various groups from upper management everyone is always looking for someone to "throw under the bus" for any mistake
- favoritism towards certain employees
- management's lack of trust in their employees and lack of support for their actions
- exclusive use of negative reinforcement (told that "no news means you are doing something right" but frequently berated for any sort of mistake)
- employees are stretched as thin as possible and overtime is rarely given but our work is overlooked by management who tell us that we do nothing and are wasting time
- questionable requests are made (i.e. no vacation until further notice)
- management often talks down to employees and treats them with little respect
- outdated approach to upper management (i.e. you work for your boss, not with your boss)
- the atmosphere feels very much like a "boys club" where men often get away with slacking off while avoiding reprimands, as well as having more opportunities for advancement, networking, and development
- employees have been referred to as "numbers" in meetings 
- little cooperation between groups due to everyone looking out for themselves
- The bank has drastically cut back support for retired  employees, they are no longer providing benefits to employees that retire
- The bank restricts any cost relating to employees (i.e. bonuses, pay raises, etc) but seemingly spends a lot of money  instituting plans that are only in effect for a few months before they are scrapped

headline: Great place to work and gain experience
pros:
Awesome company to work with. The stability is unparalleled. There was always a good stream of projects and problem solving for my job as a computer programmer. The management is always listened to the employees concerns and even though the process may have been slow, they've always provided support. That just made it very easy to work with and add value to the bank.
Since I was good at my job I could pick the projects I could work on and let the other teammates handle the support of my previous projects.
It was always a good and healthy working environment, where many teams users, BA's and support teams work together. I always felt a part of the team.
cons:
Since a bank is a big corporation sometimes the project cycles were long and there was some downtime for new projects to come in. However, when new project comes in it was always go time and I personally like that, since it leaves enough time for support and development.
The adoption of new technologies can be slow as well, but I like the stability it provides with the skills that I got during the project development and implementation stages.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: (the sound of crickets chirping...)
cons: Micro management at it's most EXTREME!  Simply copy the other big Banks years after they already rolled out their new vision and business plan with horrible adaptation and huge failure, immoral unethical and possibly illegal business practises where the bottom line is the absolute MOST important thing and "... if we have to screw a customer over to save ourselves repetitional or monetary risk, let them take us to court." - as explained to me by my manager, don't even get me started on how bad their technology is!!  (just compare the interface of their Online Banking platform to the other banks' Online Banking... it looks cheap and poor functionality!)  Recently award Canada's Most Hated Bank by JD Power and Associates.      Advice to those seeking employment at BNS:  RUN!!!!!!!!!  Go scrub toilets, give old men sponge baths or work for a sewage disposal company before considering working for this place... you'll bang your head on the walls in frustration daily and then be reprimanded for causing damage to the workplace before being declined for a Staff-Priced lending product because they "are unsure how to collect $500 of overdraft in the event it is not paid due to only being at your new BNS branch job for under 6 months." - FYI Scotiabank... YOU pay my paycheque!!!!!!! (see... rationale and reasonability don't exist here.). RUN!!!

headline: Overall Horrible Place to Work Run by Greedy Idiots
pros:
-Salary is decent
-Benefits are good
-Depending on location, coworkers can be nice
cons:
-Not paid nearly enough for the stress you have to deal with. 
-Management are entirely incompetent and training is horrible (be prepared to learn almost everything on your own or be fired).
-Corporate culture is built on selling as much as possible, ethics be damned.
-You will be shamed and ostracized for sticking up for customers and trying to sell products ethically.
-If you are not a yes-man you will not be promoted.
-You are expected to work overtime without pay, because in a sales position overtime is "voluntary".
-Sales targets and micromanagement increase every year, they are now both at absurdly high levels.
-Upper management have no clue what is happening at branch level and keep making entirely impractical recommendations that make our lives infinitely more difficult.
-Internal systems are always buggy/down and having constant problems.

headline: Mediocre Company
pros:
The people's intentions is definitely a pro, but rarely gets realized. Manager qualities varies but I've been lucky to have been paired with good managers. 

Overtime pay (level specific).

Technology wise it they tend to purchase vendor applications which gives great time to market but often lacks customization.
cons:
Management means well but rarely would go out of their way to help you achieve your goals which shows you that they do not value talent retention. The organization structure has been flattened significantly which reduces opportunities to progress your careers.
Recently took away overtime pay which was one of the main reason they were competing in salaries with other banks. Now that that's gone, they are definitely the lowest paying bank out of the top 5 in Canada.
Business processes are a nightmare and often confusing.

headline: Cheap

cons: Cutbacks on benefits (which aren't great to begin with) and cap salary increase, if any.   Indecisive management (constant reorganization in the past 5 years and wouldn't reveal to staff the permanent  office location but just keep moving staff around).   Cruel layoff (calling you in the evening not to come in the next day, leaving you with no time to say bye to your coworkers.  Such layoffs were due to reorganization and had nothing to do with firing due to poor performance).  Management refused to use the term, "outsourcing" for shifting work to new Bank branches opened outside of Toronto.  They refer outsourcing as giving work to third party vendors.

headline: Good for those specializing in tech, bad for everyone else.
pros: Mobility within the company is rather easy, especially if you start at branch level. (so from a bank teller to a downtown office worker).
cons:
Benefits leave much to be desired, pay is much lower compared to rest of the Big 5, and work is mainly contract work.  I've seen workers placed on contract for ~5 years.

 I've also seen many laid off because their jobs have become automated, so unless you work in the tech sector (a major focus of all companies now) then don't bother applying if you're hoping for job security. I've seen many co-workers who've only known Scotiabank throughout their entire working life thrown under the bus because of this.

headline: A bank that aspires to be an innovative tech company but is still clearly a traditional bank
pros:
- Recognizes it needs to transform to be more innovative and digital and has made some strides to work towards this objective
- Respectable work-life balance
cons:
- Reorganizations are executed chaotically, exacerbated  by internal/external consulting teams that make dubious, hasty recommendations to executive management based on poor data gathering and assumptions
- Digital/technology aspirations are still very much aspirational; lack-lustre execution of digital transformation initiatives,  driven primarily by desire to cut costs versus business model innovation or improving customer experience.  Not sufficient to profess the firm is now a technology company that happens to be in the financial industry but continuing to manage like a traditional bank.
- Difficult to invest in innovation when struggling to cope with huge technical debt accumulated over decades of underinvestment in core IT systems; also very poor IT governance, which allows technical debt to flourish.
- Salary not competitive with peers; difficult to attract top talent as a result
- Sense of initiative and ownership lacking across teams

headline: Could be a lot better
pros:
Job stability (for now)
Stock Options
Increasing Holidays over time
cons:
Below standard pay - usually around 20% lower for the same work at other companies
Income freezing - They have set maximum incomes for certain positions and once you hit them you will not receive any increase until they change that maximum. They only review the max every 5 years.
Changing benefits - They keep changing your benefits. Latest change will remove health benefits from retirees if they retire after 2019, and I will have 5 years left before I can retire. They also removed early retirement last year, so you have to work until 65 in order to get your pension.
Buddy Benefit - Your director and manager pick your raise and bonus at the end of the year, so you better be on their good side or you'll not get a raise or decent bonus. It used to be a set raise based on performance and you knew it at the start of the year, but now they keep you in the dark until the end of the year.
Best of Best - Managers were added to possible recipient and now only they win in my department.
Promotions are usually given to friends, not to those who work hard and deserve it. Seen many people passed up for promotions because they are not liked by the manager.
Tech from the Stone Age - Systems are out of date and crash continually. System support usually takes forever to fix something and there's too many layers of departments to go through to fix one thing.

headline: The company’s fine, but management isn’t
pros: Upward mobility ...after 6-18 months though.
cons: I worked at the CCC, and like all call centre jobs, it’s difficult, and emotionally and physically strenuous. They assign teams depending on your hours. I was supposed to be with one manager, but ended up being manager-less for about 3 months into employment due to some mixup with management. But it didn’t matter so much to me because I loved working at Scotiabank and would come early and stay late just to learn more! Then, when I got my manager, everything changed. She was the worst. She had this god-complex – an “I’m better than you” persona – and was extremely manipulative. She picked favourites, and didn’t bother connecting with you if you weren’t her favourite. She didn’t bother teaching you, but would sit there silently judging you. Moreover, my hours of work conflicted greatly with hers and the rest of the team’s, so naturally I wasn’t apart of any team meetings. I was kept out of the loop. There wasn’t any support and her advice conflicted with other managers’ advice, which she ended up overriding. For example, (since our schedules didn’t match up, this happened often) if CCC needed to make a correction on a cx’s account for an amount greater than $150, a manager has to approve it. One manager told me to submit a ticket and assured me it will get approved l to ensure the cx is happy, but once my manager came into work the next day, she immediately declined it saying this is a branch matter, and the branch manager responded back saying this is a CCC role. The branch was right and my manager was wrong; but she still wouldn’t approve the request to rightfully refund. (Note: if you work at a CCC, be prepared to go back and forth with branch representatives on what is a branch-only request and CCC-only request.) This issue ultimately led to two things 1) me to calling back the cx with the bad news, and putting a bad impression on Scotiabank all because of my managers unwillingness to budge and 2) put a bad impression on Scotiabank from an employer/employee relationship standpoint. Finally, along with being kept out of the loop, not feeling like a team, facing extreme levels of stress on your own, poor management, a constant back-and-forth with branches, be prepared for strict policies (eg. can’t keep cx on hold for more than 2mins, and how that will affect your bonus), poor wages ($17.77/hr is not enough to deal with this!), poor benefits, no unionization, disorganized envioronment, but also a stressful environment going against HR policies. For instance, I got in trouble by that same manager for using the washroom for 3-4 minutes. It was embarrassing that I had to break it down for her that getting up and walking to the  washroom from my desk took 1 minute, finding a clean stall and using the washroom in a hurry took 2 minutes, washing hands took 30 seconds, and running back to my seat took another 45seconds-1 minute. She did not care. This poor-excuse-of-a-manager only cares about the numbers and NOT the people. If you’re supposed to be on the phone for 8hrs a day, then that’s it. No time for drinking water or going to the washroom. She overworked me, took advantage, and was extremely manipulative (even if you have 5 sick days, you better bring a doctors note! Even if you have something as simple as a fever/cold and don’t usually go to the doc’s for that). She was a bully. And she was the reason I faked an excuse and quit a few days before completing my 6 month probation. She made an already-stressful job unbearable.

headline: A great place to work, for the most part
pros:
- Benefits are a huge plus and the wages are quite competitive as well
- All computer programs required for work are really easy to use
- A lot of really fun work functions
- Working hours are quite short so you can have a nice balance between work and personal activities
- HR services are excellent and offer a lot of support/knowledge
- Management offers a lot of support (for the most part at least)
cons:
- Sometimes managers will throw their own staff under the bus and humiliate them in front of other coworkers and even customers
- In some cases there isn't a lot of consistency when it comes to policy adherence. Some branches will bend to their managers wants and needs and staff won't be publicly respected by said manager unless you suck up to them
- Sometimes managers will make the rules up as they go and won't follow the key guidelines and principles of the company. Anytime a staff member doesn't follow certain made-up rules they are once again publicly humiliated in front of other staff and sometimes even customers.
- For the most part, management is very professional and respects everyone; but not all the time. In some cases managers will be very unprofessional even when customers are in the branch. For example they will be eating at their desk in full sight of customers, yell and laugh loudly or even make a personal phone call where everyone can hear them.

headline: Slash and burn management techniques.

cons: No job security, chaotic reorganizations.

headline: terrible training!!
pros: sundays off so you can spend time with family.
cons:
i have worked at Applewood mississauga branch and Westwood Mall Mississauga branch. 

Terrible training. you are given 4 months of reading to be followed by 2 months of job shadowing. Managers have no idea of the training program, because they were trained differently 100 years ago. they are not updated by headoffice how new recruits are to be trained. at my first location, manager told me to read the materials. Applewood is primarily a mature branch = where most clients are older clients, with existing accounts, mortgages, lines of credit etc. there was hardly any new accounts opening. i was told to job shadow but those would have been about complicated matters such as mortgage and estate planning, so you cant job shadow those until you have read the material related to them in your 3/4th month. 3 months in the training, i got transferred to Westwood Mall in July which was peak season for intl students in the area. here the scene was opposite. there were myriads of students accounts and credit cards - so many that the months of july and august were primary spent on students accounts opening - almost 4-5 per day. entry level recruits were given students accounts. after the student rush went down, i was told to catch up with my training - then they advised me to find out from other advisors who were available each day so i could job shadow them. but advisors were busy meeting their targets. every day meetings would get cancelled, and advisors are not good trainers because they have enough on their plates to meet weekly/monthly targets. some advisors often made up meetings and agenda in the morning meetings, because they were already many years into their work, their agenda in the mornings were not exactly matched. managers did not play any role in training. 

cronysm - one advisor got hired after me through his sister who was at another branch. and i found out he was given a dedicated advisor to train him while i did not get the same, although i had joined 3 months before him and, of course, i did not have a bro or a sis in the bank.

hazards if being team player - if u, the recruit, think u r gonna get brownie points by going the extra mile and doing something else to help the manager(s) which is not in your training plan, in the end it will bite you. stick to your training plan. if managers ask for favours and tell you take customers, you have to say NO. being nice and a "yes" person in such environment will only get you kicked out later, because you would be sacrificing your own goals to help the branch with their issues, which do not matter to you.

headline: A true high-performing team!
pros:
I joined Scotiabank in 2016 and started working in the Digital Factory - our innovation hub tasked with transforming the customer experience. There, I had the opportunity to work with the most talented group of individuals in my international career and have made significant impact to the work, culture and team. It's been an incredibly rewarding experience. 

I recently moved to another new group to the bank. Scotiabank saw this skill-set as being an important one for the bank so they invested in it's creation.I think that's pretty amazing.

If you're looking for a place that will challenge you, offer meaningful training / development opportunities and give you access to some of the best leaders in the business (technology, retail banking, operations etc.) than this is the place for you.
cons: Some processes need to be re-designed but it's in the works!

headline: A good foot in the door of the company, but not a job you want long term
pros:
Great, friendly team for the most part. 
Interesting job- you will learn a lot about personal banking
Good benefits and employee perks
Plenty of opportunity to move up in the company
Pro and con- Your manager can pretty much make or break you. Some managers are very approachable and personable, others are a nightmare to deal with.
cons:
Essentially dealing with unhappy customers all day, which can wear on you. Customers are often irate and verbally abusive.

Inconsistent employee development and support. You will only get your managers' attention and continuous training if you are bad at your job. Those who do good work are rarely given more opportunity to learn and take on more responsibility, or they are sent for training which they never actually get the opportunity to use.

Employee issues when brought to HR are rarely addressed and completely resolved.

People who have been with the company a long time can pretty much get away with anything even if there have been several complaints made against them.

Job can become monotonous once you've been there 6+ months and get the hang of things. A lot of taking the same types of calls and answering the same issues over and over all day long. 

A lot of adjustments are made to the job and IT system without consulting the people who are actually doing the job or have to use the new system, which leads to a lot of frustration, unreasonable expectations, and system problems.

headline: Some progress but still a long ways to go.
pros:
Some of the people are great. They really care about the job and each other. 
A few of the managers are amazing and want to help you improve and grow. 
Upper management has been trying to shake the “Sweat Shop” mentality. Working conditions have improved over the past few years.
cons:
Harassment and bullying are still an issue. 
Some low-level managers can still be heard shouting insults from their desk at people as they walk by. Complete lack of respect for the people under their leadership. I find it disgusting. Depending on who is involved, you will either get a positive result if you try to stop it. Or be forced to quit. It’s often the case that people start a role and decide to leave a few months into it. Exiting comments are very similar among those that choose to leave: Poor work/life balance, people are rude and disrespectful at times(referring to management and peers), poor training and unbelievably, blatant favoritism. 
Some departments are still considered “Sweat Shops”.

headline: Canada's Most International Bank - Big Organization, Big Pros and Big Cons
pros: Scotiabank is a very large organization with an extensive bureaucracy, polices and procedures governing almost every conceivable aspect of the business.  These can help reduce errors and at their best allow for a consistent approach across the breadth of the bank.  Its size and built in redundancy makes it resilient and it can be a stable place to work (depending on your business unit and business line).  An entire career can be spent in this organization quite comfortably if you are lucky to have the right combination of a good business unit, great coworkers and a good boss.  The leadership program, specifically in terms of curriculum,  was probably amongst the best in the industry.
cons: As a large organization, experiences can vary by a very significant variance between teams, business units, organizations and business lines.  Some organizations within the bank prize initiative while others want drones.   Some require teamwork while others (inadvertently) emphasize individual effort at the expense of co-workers.  The plethora of policies and procedures can hinder as much as help, becoming proverbial red tape that disrupts, delays or prevents the right things from happening at the right times.

headline: Scotia Dealer Advantage, Customer Service Rep
pros:
- Co-workers are fun people
- Pension
cons:
- VERY poor pay, well below market
- Fiscally irresponsible (announced Christmas party, only to cancel it in September claiming "no money" and didn't even have the respect to talk about it in our Town Hall)
-	EXTREMELY micromanaged (every last detail)
-	Goal to provide excellent customer service – with a time limit of only a few minutes before it affects your performance; nitpicky on “quality” to the point where some of the objectives are unattainable and you are openly compared to your co-workers during “coaching” sessions
-	Can’t even say good morning to your co-workers without getting the stink-eye for “chatting”
-	TOTALITARIAN environment
-	Best suited for kids fresh out of school who know no better; most adults would run screaming from the regime of management knowing that there are infinitely WAY better opportunities elsewhere

headline: Great company to work for it you are under 30

Difficult to gain employment if you do not know someone - they do not look at external hires very often

Most businesses are singly focused - not focused on the overall enterprise strategy - cross team collaboration still an issue

headline: New VPs only care about stock price
pros:
+Pension plan if we you want to stay long

cons:
- The bank wants to reduce OPEX at expense of employees benefits/salary so they can increase their net profits and thus the price of the stocks.
- They have many give to community events but almost 100% of the proceeds come from voluntary donations from employees and not from the bank itself. Basically they are very cheap. 
- VPs won't listen to their staff's feedback.
- They used to say you don't get higher salary but you get job security, last year there were massive layoffs.
- I 'm rating them bad in work/life balance because the want to get away from work from home, just because someone said others are doing so..

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: The only pro is that there is a salary that is paid on time. This job is nothing but a paycheque. If you have a good manager the office environment can be good. Work life balance is good because no one works overtime after the bank got sued for forcing people to without pay.
cons:
The sales goals are absurd, and they grow every year. When goals go up significantly without any increase in pay, its the same as a paycut. The incentive pay is a joke, especially when its near impossible to reach the required sales. The base salaries start off far below market as well. 
Do whats right for the client is a catch phrase that means very little. The turnover rate is very high and there are chronic issues with staffing, making it much harder on the remaining branch staff.

- How can you practice to do a line of credit if no one comes in to apply for one? (entire training/product practice if placed at a low traffic branch)
- why are some employees at high traffic branches (Square One) praised as the best advisors when their traffic is many times higher as other branches?

headline: Nothing like advertised
pros: Great Physical space. If you are self motivated you can use your time there to grow . Theres zero pressure to actually get anything done.
cons:
The job is simply not what was advertised. The Digital Factory (DF) was sold to me as an innovation hub where a honed agile process rapidly generated world class solutions which were iterated on. 

The reality is that the agile process is pure theatre, most of the scrum masters are very weak and lots of the employees are not even familiar with basic agile practises. The DF is beholden to the larger bank so the release cycle is too long to do any real iterative development anyway. Another result of this relationship between DF and the bank is that basically nothing gets released, you are essentially building prototypes to the whims of whichever scotia exec is sponsoring your team at that moment (expect the sponsor, and therefore your requirements, to change pretty regularly).

As nothing gets released theres no sense of satisfation in a job well done, on the plus side, there are no real deadlines, just do as much work as you want! Gets old though.

headline: Client service
pros:
Staff where fun and helpful to work with.
Community events where wonderful.
bonus system was alright .
loads of information at hand to learn from.
Professional environment (mostly).
felt good the first year (prior to AB mass layoffs)
cons:
Start out at below market pay.
You are not recognized for past experience; and are paid the same as someone fresh out of school. 
Goals and stats increase to the point of almost unbearable amounts to perfect although they can be done you must try very hard or work through breaks or before/after work starts.
People are not spoken to if they work on breaks or before/after work starts and are able to keep pace with unrealistic requirements.
Work is consistently taken out of country IE: laid off entire center in Alberta then hire more people in Mexico and Columbia, should be servicing Canadians with Canadians, where ever able. 
No ability to renegotiate contract, even when having the experience and being one of the top contributors of her/his peers; because of said experience.
Top yearly bonus only 1 of 1000 people get, in yearly review, or know the right people.
Scotia Bank cares more about the share holders then client or employee. In my honest opinion banks should not have shares it makes for a corrupt and harsh environment. ( This thought came to mind from Brian Porter talking about share holdings)

headline: great experience...but not for everyone
pros:
- colleagues are always willing to help and collaborate
- Able to network quite extensively across branches and district as managers and employees move around often and there are large events -  performance is ranked so you can become a "celebrity" or closest thing to it if you perform well, everyone wants to meet you, knows of you etc 
- lots of knowledge and training learnt A LOT about personal finance and mortgages/investing - knowledge that is practical despite career path 
- Well oiled machine always a department or unit to call for help and everyone knows their role and how to get things done
cons:
- long hours and lots of weekends/overtime to finish deals that isn't  compensated or recognized. manager only sees results not effort and OT to get it done
- easy to get pigeon holed in retail sector and not given corporate opportunities - lots of advancement in branch but not throughout company 
- pressure to perform and deliver every single day, no grace period or slowing down as soon as one deal closes management expects another
- downsizing meant more responsibility lots of smaller administrative tasks and unnecessary  jobs passed on to advisors taking time away from more pressing matters and frustrations expecting to be and do everything

headline: Accounting Officer
pros:
Easy job very straightforward

Managers could be nice depending on who it is.

Stock purchase plan
cons:
Managers pushing you to meet ridiculous daily quotas.

Seriously if you have a good manager your job will be great. For the first 4 months I had a laid back friendly manager then all of a sudden a senior manager from another department came in, tried to cut costs, added more work, and tried to save the bank money This made the job more stressful. They introduce unnecessary controls to see if you slack off. People dont have time to take all their breaks. The enviornment is depressing.

If you havent worked in a bank before, just know that they care more about their stocks performance than the employees. Theyre investing crazy amounts of money in technology so that most of these back office processes will be automated by 2023.

cons:

headline: IT analyst
pros:
Good give-and-take in regards to shift start and end times. If you're late, management will not give you trouble since you can make up for the lost time.  

Freedom to innovate and create process improvements (but which job /wouldn't/ allow this?)

Friendly culture. Very rare cases of rudeness from internal customers. Management has your back if customers complain.
cons:
The usual boring "silo" IT work. Meaning, in large complex systems and processes involving many teams, separation of duties ensures you get a very very very small piece of the process to work on, and you repeat that monotonously on a daily basis until you leave your job for a new role.

Have seen managers win awards for an employee's hard work. 

Support shifts which require evening/night/weekend work for 7 days (on top of your regular day shift) are too frequent and demanding, and make work/life balance impossible during those weeks.

headline: Stuck in the past
pros: Seemed promising from the interview, as they said they care about your career growth.
cons:
For everything you have to do, the pay isn't worth it. The term "specialist" means you still do all other jobs too.  
Permanent position but you sign an agreement that cements you in your shift and your position (18months). Asking for time off for school, life, or go to a new department, they will refer back to that agreement.....
You get in trouble if you try to implement new ways to facilitate tasks.
They made an announcement when we allowed email as a way to communicate to members....in 2016, we used fax and mail previously.

headline: Worst place I have ever worked.
pros: Flexible hours for students, and reasonable pay.
cons: They would switch my schedule the day before a shift without letting me know and then if I missed the shift because I was unaware I had one they wouldn't call me to let me know until 5 minutes before the scheduled shift would end. Convoluted phone system made it impossible to contact and ask when shifts were, also made it practically impossible to call in sick. Part-time employees treated like dirt, as a student I was forced to become a full time employee during school breaks without being asked. Condescending management team with little respect for the needs of their staff. Enraged clients because it was impossible to book an appointment with an advisor.

headline: Gone to Another Company
pros: Job security for the most part. Job security used to be incredible until new CEO came in. Financial services benefits. Reputable company.
cons:
-Work life balance is horrible. Overtime must be approved in advance - so staying to finish up your days work (when your boss has gone home) is unpaid. 
-Numbers are your only performance drivers now so things like volunteer work and going above and beyond don't matter. 
-Performance awards now decided by district level - people who don't even work with you. 
-Career movement potential is limited. Even with excellent performance ratings my biggest raise was $1000. 
-Recognition is nearly non-existent
-You are expected to fit into a template and do the job that way rather than working with people which is what we do

cons: The bank only cares about making money, not about the staff wellbeing. From job cuts, to horrible pension scheme etc. Things were good back then untill that CEO. Management leaks out information from their meeting and trickle it down to junior staffers. "Very dishonest". Management would watch supervisors treat their subordinates horribly and do nothing.

Scotiabank used to be the bank in Canada that people liked to work for  - no longer. Employee morale is low and the annual employee survey is seeing lower and lower scores.

cons:
- Company's target for women in VP+ positions still stuck at 30% after over 10 years of having the same goal
- After change in leadership, women and minority were either ousted or moved to non P&L positions
- Leadership looks extremely white and male
- Digital Leadership seems to be taken its clues from Silicon Valley - lots of men in hoodies, just younger than the men in the older bank

headline: Stay away from the Call Centre
pros:
The people I worked with (not managers) were great. They made a very stressful work environment easier with jokes and snacks. 

The applause points you receive from team challenges, positive reviews etc. are great, you can cash them in for gift cards or products. (I got a lot of movie passes and a hairdryer) 

They give you benefits from day one of training! I got new glasses in my 2nd week of training.
cons:
The job is super stressful! Call after call with angry customers threatening/yelling at you because of someone else's mistake (usually the branch) that you can't fix. 

Working weekends means that nothing you do for the customer will actually process that day as it takes 2-3 business days. When the branch messes up they have no accountability and it can count as a negative review for you. 

Micro managers that harass you over your stats even when you are making the stats! What's the point of making the stats if you still get harassed about it?

She had her favorites, who she would use to terrorize employees not up to "par". She would promise them promotions in return, but she never does lol. Additionally most managers were like that, a lot of power struggles.

headline: Best Bank to work for out of THE BIG 5!
pros: Being a Financial Advisor, it's given that we have sales targets to reach, but with BNS stellar products from Day to Day to Credit Products and Investment Portfolios, it makes my life easier to beat the other banks whenever I compare what BNS has than the other banks. TD and RBC are in their mature years hence they hesitate to provide too much perks that people can take advantage because it boils down to COST. It's a reduction to their profit if they try to cater great value rewards to millions of their customers, but with BNS, being the third in rank,it has still so much room to develop and reach that top spot in the long run. As for CIBC and BMO, they are way too far behind the BIG 3 to be compared with RBC, TD and BNS. Plus paywise, I kid you not, BNS has the better pay. Because I've applied at TD and CIBC just for the sake of wondering if they'd offer a better pay, TD pay is really bad CIBC is way better than TD but Scotia still beats it. I can't tell for BMO and RBC as I have not been successful to get to the job offer part in my applications with them. I wouldn't betray BNS though. It has proven me that working in the Alberta area, i don't have to kiss anyone's butt just to be promoted. I got promoted in less than a year, because of exceeding my targets immensely. Training program of BNS is absolutely the best thing that happened to BNS. Almost all the best performing Financial Advisors in Alberta are those who have gone through the rigorous training where only the best trainees gets to be successfully become Financial Advisors. It's been a pivotal component in stepping to the role when you've been prepared and have learned the fundamentals of what your work would look like.
cons: Long Term Disability benefit! It's not anymore bank paid, but what the bank did was increase our health spending account and if we want to avail the Long Term Disability, we can use the health spending account to be deposited to our account as our pay, and then LTD will be deducted from the pay after taxes. Wish gym membership could be incorporated to wellness program. Lol. I don't like the fact that a lot of our contact centre agents pretend to be know it all when it comes to people's banking, misleading our clients and booking the appointment to us, only to find out that when client is in my office, it's either they're not qualified, or it's impossible for the branch to process it for them.

headline: A lot of opportunities to grow, but a lot of internal conflict.

cons: A lot of internal conflict and instability.

headline: Corrupt Local management.
pros: NO benefit to work in this useless organization.
cons: Highly greedy managers in the branches. Who take credit for the work done by the lower leverl employees. You have to work for 11 to 12 hours without any benefit. Lots of discrimation and torture and harrassament by the branch managers. Totally impersonal environment no values.

Also, Spanish speakers definitely have more opportunities to move up due to the nature of the business.

cons:
Unrealistic expectations, they are incredibly demanding. Salary for an FA4 is way below the industry, $40k to start and you are questioned by everyone along the way while on training specially when you have to read a lot and been challenged as of how much you are actually retaining.

Their model is ridiculous as you have to know the CEM, do the appointment interview, the full CIS and total view, you will always be asked as of why you didn't get more business from the original reason and it's all about pushing into the digital channels and you are expected to stay extra hours because you have to do the Mopping Tomorrow

As a new Financial Advisor you are expected to retain everything you learn, go the extra mile, be really aggressive with your attitude , you will have to report to your in branch coach, learning facilitator, call instructor and you will be given all kinds of centralized opportunities from customers who only have one product and you will have to proof the bank that you can sell at least 2-3 more products (go figure, you just started yet they so expect you to know all their products and services. Good luck learning everything involved in a STEP restructure)

If you have your PFP/CFP and think you will be doing financial planning good luck as they are so pushy with lending and if your branch is on the "wave" a fully qualified Senior FA will spend 2-3 hours in cash as a teller or with the iPad helping the line up

The worst model and bank I have worked

headline: Bank is going downhill
pros: Great group of co-workers and perks of being staff. I can't say much else as it has been going downhill for staff over the past 5 years.
cons:
Management is either really good or really bad. Some management loves to hold you back.
Sales goals are very high and aggressive and compensation is lacking.

headline: Associate Business Analyst

headline: Nice company, but salaries are not competitive

headline: Unprofessional unorganized company: Don't recommend it
pros: The pay and benefits are decent.

Training for staff is unorganized and it was not followed through No support for growth, only if manager liked you, you will be visible to others: no contact or hardly any interaction with DBM or VP or other coaches. Lack of privacy among other peers/management, didn't feel comfortable sharing anything with manager since all that was told would be shared back to employees.

Recently it became part of our job to also be a teller on demand, which is overwhelming at times with the high sales targets. Proactive calls are also an important part of the job. I find my job extremely stressful

headline: Verification and Dealer Funding Rep
pros:
*This is actually a review for subsidiary of Scotia Bank Scotia Dealer Advantage in Burnaby, BC and not Scotia Bank itself, but had to select "Scotia Bank" as there was none (yet) for Scotia Dealer Advantage.

Plenty of "moral boosting" activities like pizza and Chinese food lunches, Annual team Meeting,  etc.
cons:
Fun activities do not compensate for:

 - shoddy starting salary

 - overly crowded 3rd and 4th floors with nearly constantly busy washrooms = no personal space, even on breaks. Isles where staff is situated often too narrow with people constantly bumping the backs of other employees' chairs - most annoying.

 - being blown on full throttle by air conditioning from fall through winter!??

 - constant petty rules (2 separate 5-digit codes to enter into phone when first logging on in the morning, as well as umpteen other passwords and codes to enter when logging in to desktop programs and when stepping away from desk)

 - way too many nosy supervisors (which, I'm guessing is largely why the starting salaries for new hires is ridiculously low and not "at par" with other major banks)  who all way over micro-manage (mine would actually call me whenever I was running late - something I'd never experienced in ANY OTHER WORKPLACE!) Felt more like I was back in elementary school!?? These many supervisors could often be seen giggling and engaging in non-work-related "gab fests" while the "underlings" had to have "nose to the grindstone."

 - you are required to open a Scotia bank account for direct deposit of pay. So in my case, every pay day, I had to first go to Scotia to withdraw 500/day of pay (that was my daily maximum allowed for withdrawal) and then deposit it to my primary bank. So at least 2 trips to 2 separate banks every single pay day = MAJOR INCONVENIENCE!!! 

 - extremely high turnover

headline: Senior Relationship Manager
pros: Can't think of any except the free banking. It was a disappointing experience and I could not recommend it there. Stay away!!
cons: Very disorganized and lack of vision and conflicting strategies. Terrible place to work. Poor training and leadership from the top is non existent.

headline: Don't work here!
pros: -paycheque, and some good people. That's really all I can think of. Most of the people I work with hate there job.
cons: It's bad! My basic day is getting asked how many financial plans I do or how maybe pacs I sell. My boss doesn't talk to me other wise. Even if I met my goals there is always some mundane thing. Let's say you met your sales goal but didn't have 18 meetings a week or enough marketing calls you would be lucky to get a quality rating. District management has no idea what is going on in branches. Branch management bullies and harasses staff, maybe talk to you staff and see what's going on and respect what they say v

headline: Lending services Officer
pros: 9-5 no overtime. Great salary and benefits for the city. Fantastic work culture
cons: All the goods are dead. Scotiabank is now left to the monsters who fire us all. All non Toronto sites that are non branch are being closed. There are rumours they are cutting newspaper delivery to the investment department. The rulers are cheap and do not mind cutting people.

headline: Campus Recruiter
pros: Great team. A very stable and secure job. I always felt great pride in working for such a well known and well respected company.
cons: Slow pace. Lack of innovation- I hated being told that the reason we did something in a particular way was "because that's how it's always been done." Bureaucracy!!!!

headline: Look Elsewhere
pros: Large company, job security is fairly good. Limited room for growth. Many locations.
cons: Internal job applications are now processed at a high level which limits your growth. Recent change in CEOs creates an uncertainty in regards to job security. New CEO centralized almost everything to Toronto which also limits growth. Company did major lay offs during economic mix downturn in Alberta. No care for people. My highest raise in my 9 years was 2% (I am a top performer).

headline: Good company, decent pay and benefits, horizontal movement possible!
pros: As any bank, tons of politics going on in the company, when I was employed, there was a restructuring going on to shape the departments in a good way. New procedures were also being implemented, however I left to go back to school.
cons: Many employees in managerial level without any degrees, qualifications, but have been with the company for over 30 years. Difficult to move up but networking and connections matters most!! Company is full of employees, their friends and family members.

headline: director
pros: Nice working relationship among colleagues.
cons: Slow pace; need to improve work efficiency.

headline: Assistant Manager
pros: Good opportunity for growth within the company.
cons: Increasing sales pressure from district level management

headline: It was ok
pros: They had some good training, and the job is pretty laid back, nothing too stressful or anything like that.  Just an ok customer service thing.
cons: My co-workers were honestly pretty bad.  They were very lazy and I had to pick up the slack for them, but I got blamed sometimes.

headline: Accounting policy
pros: Lots of opportunity if management like you and you can do personal things during work hours. Otherwise you are stuck!
cons: Most people have no strong technical knowledge. Rely on copying others work to get by. Favoritism is evident in job allocation. Ones that don't get debit/credit are assigned important jobs. As a result an army is required to do a simple task that can be done by 1-2 people!

headline: Bright future for this bank, soured by poor culture.
pros: Strong change program, taking the right steps to transform legacy business. It has a good global footprint, lots of international opportunity.
cons: Culture is tough, the system at scotia is not welcoming to newcomers. Very process oriented, most people have worked there their whole lives.

headline: Scotia
pros: Large company that has alot of opportunity. If management likes you, you're golden to advance.
cons: Politics between departments. Lots of people just sitting there waiting to retire. Not as well pay as other finance companies.

headline: Stable job
pros: stable, difficult to be dismissed, good enough vacation and medical package, good profit sharing program, friendly working environment
cons:
Low Pay, low turn over rate, hard to move up the ladder
repetitive work (daily, weekly, monthly, annual)

headline: A disruptive transformation at work
pros: I'm relatively new to banking, and from what I've heard of other banks, Scotiabank has an advantage for those seeking to grow from being less structured and organized. It is a good employer for many. It is also in the middle of a transformation that is opening up some great opportunities.
cons: If you seek a highly organized and structured work environment where you are one part of a larger smooth running machinery, you'll be disappointed in Scotiabank. It is in the midst of a massive transformation, and it was always a little less structured than, let's say RBC or CIBC. Being in the midst of a transformation means, you can either be amongst those enjoying some of the sweetest rewarding work environments, or those that are marked for questioning. So the cons is essentially that there is just a high level of uncertainty at Scotiabank at this time.

headline: Manager Lending Services
pros: International, well recognized and good standing Financial Institution.
cons: Currentlly downsizing staff.

headline: CSR
pros:
- Great jobs to place on resume and gain skills in the workforce
- Great team environment (colleagues)
-ESOP
cons: As staff members we are also customers of Scotiabank. There are many factors that influence our loyalty to Scotiabank as customers, people who invest into Scotiabank financially. The way that we are treated within the workplace, the quality of customer solutions offered, and overall competitiveness with other financial institutions. There is a lot that needs improvement and sometimes being a Scotiabank employee and customer at the same time becomes conflicting. Other cons include a lack of leadership within the management structure, outdated processes, and employees forced onto to sales floor without proper or full training.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Hard to think of any other than a steady pay check
cons:
Impossible sales goals and targets, extreme micro management. Sales targets are only thing that matters, customers are numbers , staff ideas and input are heavily frowned upon.
Only way to make targets is to oversell to clients and work long unpaid hours 
Stressful and negative workplace. Knowledgable employees are leaving in droves, staff left are untrained and completely unable to do the job. Hard to see customers being treated this way

headline: Director
pros: Compensation can be good if negotiated
cons: Toxic environment that is overly political

headline: Poor culture
pros: Good pay, esop and way to learn about finance
cons: Recent changes mean daily meetings where managers shame you if enough product wasn't sold or you aren't meeting targets. Scotiabank used to have an advice and planning culture, now it has a sell 3 credit cards, 2 pacs and 4 savings accounts to each customer culture. There have also been major efficiency losses thanks to a new resl review process that makes mortgages very hard to approve. Managers afraid of Getting a bad resl score delay sending files, and corrections to files can not be appealed. I had one mortgage where papers were done two weeks ahead of time, but thanks to resl and my manager, still didn't have approval the day before funding. Very upset with the recent changes and culture of fear that has cropped up.

headline: senior analyst
pros: salary package include medical, dental etc. plus pension; position  at west coast basically provided service support to the user departments; both in-house & east coast; its only an operational site at west coast; all development dedicated at Ontario.
cons: not very much opportunities at west coast in terms of development; so far only users support, custom reporting and data cube enhancement. West coast satellite site operates by its own; and very few technical position. Probably its an operational site so not very interested in new technology nor new approach, such as data visualization for BI or Cloud based options you can forget it - if you managed to stick with the bank forever then its a good choice but if the bank decided to let go ( need to survive under its own political environment  -> very high turn over rate) - then you may stuck with out-dated skill sets  ; plus expected to work or check e-mail after hours or Saturday - that's why they will give you the phone on the top of laptop ( not to keep but need to return to the bank when your service is terminated )

headline: Senior Accounting Clerk
pros: Certain amazing people to work with. Nice workplace, free online learning courses. Great learning experience
cons: Too much office politics, low pay, lack of leadership to certain individuals, repetitive work

headline: Customer service reprenatative-a great opportunity with scotia bank

headline: Eh

headline: Customer Service Representative

cons: The bank is changing and thats one of the reasons I decided to leave. The CEO doesn't care about the service staff anymore. There has been so many layoffs. They are also going through these Waves, which made some employees reapply for their own jobs. They have become so heartless. Cutting hours to employees that have been there a long time, so they can hire someone cheaper. Its just not a pleasant environment. The managers are under a lot of stress and take it out on the staff.

headline: Great place to work!

headline: General

cons: Slow to react to changing market dynamics. Reluctant to invest in new capabilities to achieve desired growth. Lacks conviction when new business models are attempted and gives up too early.

headline: bank

headline: Virtual Small Business Advisor

I have a fantastic team that I work with and my Manager is extremely supportive of allowing me to get ahead in my career.
cons:
Well the paperwork can be cumbersome, as is with most banks.
Occasionally younger staff members feel that they are being held back, which is common in many large organizations. I personally have yet to feel this but it is a common discussion with SYP members in different business lines.

headline: Bank Teller

Productive

headline: Law Clerk
pros: Flexible work arrangements, ability to take on new responsibilities, bonus,

headline: Exploitive
pros: Clients (Scotiabank prefers customers) are great! Most co-workers are a pleasure to work with.
cons: Sales goals are impossible to reach in a regular work week. They lost a class action lawsuit for unpaid overtime, and the demands have only increased. They are not interested in quality of life for their employees, only saving costs (have eliminated back office support) and boosting profits. Pay and benefits are low compared to the competition. Morning meetings are equivalent to a daily verbal lashing.

headline: Casuals Not Treated as Equal
pros:
My local branch-level management is great (there are just so many layers of hierarchy above them it is hard to get anything done)
Nice to have a discount on banking services.
cons:
Tons of uncertainty going forward. Employees understand why the changes are good for the bank but stop trying to get our buy-in when it means fewer jobs.
Pays so little that I cannot afford childcare; can only work when my spouse is off to avoid paying for childcare as I can't even break even. There are more shifts I could work, but it just isn't worth it to pay more for daycare than I bring in. Not really a living wage.
Organization does not treat Casual employees as equals, even with things like the annual Viewpoint Survey. Also very disappointing to not be able to participate in the stock option plan. I have been casual for one year and have worked every week, hard to not feel a bit sour about being excluded from these things... Especially Viewpoint. It seems like the casual's opinions just don't matter at all.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Moving towards an innovative global digital transformation, Scotiabank has many opportunities in all different areas. It is a great place to work.
cons: Salary is not as competitive

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Great place to work at!
cons: Unfortunately low paying role in the company

headline: financial advisor
pros: Good training, pay for education
cons: impossible goals, pressure to work through breaks, outside of business hours.

headline: From the VP office
pros: Exciting strategy and a few great leaders
cons: Poor change management and lack of empowerment of non-executive staff

headline: Manager of Personal Banking
pros:
- great coworkers
- lots of opportunity for growth & advancement for those people who are willing to self develop and relocate
- extensive benefits/employee perks (though many are useless to the average Joe)
cons:
- employee satisfaction and engagement has declined dramatically in the last 3 years as the Bank transitions onto a more digital path.  Staff are inundated with unnecessary and cumbersome policies, combined with a 10% reduction to staffing nationwide (in the last 12 mo) and often unachievable sales targets.
- the "customer first" motto is a sham as the Bank is clearly focused only increasing shareholder value.
- what was once a company know for respecting and taking care of it's staff, now considers anyone below the management level to be expendable.  Staff turnover is +30% inside the first year of hire.

headline: Underpaid
pros: Great people to work with
cons: inconsistent management, one manager tells you something another tells you the opposit

headline: typical big 5 bank
pros:
good managers that provide support and listen to feedback
good hours (for an employee) for retail banking
good public image among Canadians
cons:
aggressive sales goals that increase every year
outdated technology

headline: Director - Corporate Function Role
pros:
Scotiabank is a large, diverse organization with a significant international footprint. It offers a wide variety of roles in many countries that allows someone to develop a broad career in multiple disciplines. 
The company offers reasonable benefits. 
Vacation time is good and generally based on number of hours worked, they also allow someone to carry over 5 days if they are not used. They provide 3 personal obligation days that cannot be carried over but can be used as required. 
The company will pay for Spanish lessons.
Lots of opportunity to learn. However more conducive for people who are self taught.
cons: Scotiabank systems and processes are poorly out of date. The bank relies heavily on legacy systems and a patchwork of old systems layered on top of each other. To provide some perspective it is like looking at old plumbing done by an inexperienced handyman with a collection of copper, lead, electrical conduit and plastic pipes held together with duct tape, glue and solder. Rather than fix the core problems work continues with more patchwork.

headline: Would Not Recommend

cons: Difficult to move. Long hours. Strict and hard deadlines with many conflicting tasks. Not supported well by management. Not privy to what is going on in the bank - kept as silos. Are reliant on many other departments to get simple processes done yet not given access. Must be willing to take the brunt of client complaints on a regular basis - they will always be directed to you to fix even if you have no control or authority over the situation or an ability to resolve it.

headline: If you're a developer, best to avoid this company
pros:
Some talented developers and engineers work there
Some really great people to work with
cons:
Poor pay compensation compared to other banks for the IT industry
Laying off programmers and engineers despite the CEO claiming they can't find enough of them
Hiring a large number of contract workers from India
Terrible benefits system
Pensions are no longer defined, they are now matched contributions only
Promotions rarely make sense, and are sometimes completely baffling
Despite much internal advertising about work life balance, it simply doesn't exist.  I have seen people with children leave because of the poor integration of work life balance available to them.
Routine layoffs

headline: Business Analyst  specialist- International

Gain knowledge  (by yourself)
Transportation between buildings
Good place to start
cons:
Pay low than the average
Lack of management with experience 
No work/life balance
You're not allow to move to another area. If you want your life at Scotiabank will be hell thanks to management.
No career path support 
Extra hours- no compensation 
Some lazy coworkers and management team does nothing about it
Book your vacation is a lottery 
Not support for training and professional development 
There is not enough space for desk. Sometimes there are 2 people in one single desk. Too much people for the building (real state at Scarborough)

headline: Stay away and leave fast if you are already there
pros:
Good friendly atmosphere
Very dedicated staff; even to a fault
Promotes a positive culture (but at the expense of staff morale)
cons:
Staff underpaid within the market and several divisions within BNS underpay even more.  If you are not shaking hands with the client and generating profits, you are undervalued and underpaid.
Technology will soon replace you!
Branch staff on contract of medical leave were all recently laid off.
CEO is money hungry.  Mr. Porter comes off as trying to set the bank up for long term success but when the majority of his salary is based on share performance, he sets a poor tone.  Current staff going through lay offs all pay the price for his salary.

headline: Scotiabank - A shell of their former selves
pros: A job to pay bills. Average benefits but at least benefits.  Accessible with car or transit. No banking fee which helps right.
cons:
Too many politics. A DIRECTOR or VP will sacrifice you when they screw up and those types screw up a lot.  We saw lots of Senior Mgrs and Managers fired because of the mistakes of their bosses.
Salaries and benefits below average and there is a reason Scotiabank no longer in the Canada's Most Admired list.  Long hours in IT and other depts so really you're making like 10 dollars an hour.  Lots of Directors and VPs with poor, old skills. They just know how to talk in mtgs and go for coffee with other upper mgmt. 
Never spend money on training, promotion still about who you know, not what you know.  Director and VP will never support you if doing soon takes courage.  All the good people already left. Just 3 types now: 1. young people out of school, 2. Old people couldn't get a job anywhere else and 3. People sending out their resumes

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: The people I worked with for 8 years were amazing. I was extremely satisfied with the culture, structure, and employee growth opportunities that were available.
cons: Key note from my 'pros' section of comments: PAST TENSE. With the recent structural changes, not only did I see a shift in culture and employee satisfaction, I saw an unwillingness to offer career advancement opportunities unless it's within a branch. Management does everything possible to keep FA's within the branch system, where I feel there is no growth opportunity past being a branch manager. I used to be proud to work for Scotiabank. I left at the right time.

headline: Scotiabank is a terrible company these days
pros: Hmmm, not much these days. You get a salary if you stay quiet and don't make waves. Don't try to look for another job in another dept, may get fired for it
cons:

- employees fearful of getting fired so working overtime just to hold onto jobs
- heard pregnant lady got fired right after announcing pregnancy
- heard someone in GTB fired after father died and on same day learned wife pregnant (what the??)
- still see employees who are "favorites" - those types that do less work than others and just sit on their butts sending emails, taking lots of smoking breaks and one guy on our floor plays video games all day on his phone!
- terrible benefits compared to other companies
- seems like the worst performing stock on TSX (I'm sure there are worse)

headline: Small Business Advisor
pros: Great opportunity to learn a lot on your own. You get to work with people who have a lot of experience and knowledge in the banking area. Good opportunities to saving on banking fees and credit cards
cons: Terrible training system. Management usually has very little Small Business experience. This field is setup to almost make you fail. It is very difficult to get what you need due to the lack of information. You are forced to figure it out on your own without knowing if you are doing work correctly or not.

headline: The good, the bad, the ugly. 2.5/5 - A good Job, not a career.
pros: Excellent inside knowledge on how colleagues and clients get ahead. Good combination of DBPP and ESOP, with option to be a contributory pensioner plus max 6% of salary into share ownership which they match 50%. The wise would realize that its basically two pensions, and defined benefit and defined contribution. They truly believe in qualifying the advisor by using constant requirements for continued education. Excellent product suite and very good departmentalization support (for units dedicated for employee support) Decent pay, but not the best. Managers are usually a wealth of experience (could be good and bad)
cons: A huge disconnect between the pay scales for the levels of job. Seniority does play a role, but the jobs are very similar. Extremely unrealistic performance metrics. Sure, your a Financial Advisor (salesman/lady) and your job is to sell. Terrible amounts of cold calling (don't let them tell you its a warm call they are only kidding themselves) Goals and metrics based on how/if/when your customers use mobile/online banking. Yes they give you targets on "demonstrating" how to use non-branch banking options. And your either clawed back or rewarded based on If that customer uses the non-branch solution. Not to mention your customers also have to "use" their product prior to you receiving full credit for your sale.(not commission, but tracked sales) They use a tactic for customer experience by calling a recent visited customer to complete a survey on how their experience was. Problem is that they use way too small of a sample size for these goals/actuals to be a true reflection, and the output effects your Annual Appraisal as a branch, which we all share whether its good or bad. Dog eat Dog with other advisors and VERY clicky (watch where you plant your flag) There is not an open door with the manager regardless of what they say. You even "get in trouble" for calling HR with your concern before consulting your manager. No transparency at all. Managers all have their own sets of rules and definitely have their favourite employees. Terrible core benefits, and very expensive upgraded benefits.

headline: Stressful Job, Low Pay, Competitive Environment, Fake Culture
pros: Health insurance is really the only benefit. But goodluck getting time off to visit the doctor!
cons:
Seems like the only folks willing to take (and remain) in these positions at Scotiabank are young folks undecided in life that get sold a dream that if they work hard they will rise to a position actually worth being there. This is partially true but totally not worth the pittance of a pay you receive for said hard work.

The pay is REALLY LOW! REALLLLLLLLLLYYYYYYY LOW! You cannot have a family to support, bills to pay, goals of saving money while working here! It is almost impossible. Even overtime is paid at the same base rate as your regular hours. Is that legal?

BUT, if your dream job is sales, then go for it!

This job is more about sales of products and services than transactional processing. But its not commissioned based, so forget about being duly compensated for bringing in new business.

Also there is a trickle down effect of pressure where the lower staff members are often aggressively intimidated by management to work harder to keep branch numbers where they should be. Scotiabank Trinidad has no union, so management can practically do what they want...invent new rules by the day, and you HAVE to follow it. or else...

It is a tense, strict and micromanaged place to work. And I would not recommend working there as a lower-level employee.

headline: Accounting Officer - Transfers In
pros: Great job security, and roles are very specific so you always know what is expected of you.  Fellow coworkers were great.  Little overtime required.
cons:
Low salary and minimal vacation time. Management of the team I worked on was bad- the person was new to the role and doesn't have natural people skills and there didn't seem to be much coaching to help the person improve.  
Scotia is a huge company, but this role is back office, which is lowest on the totem pole and Scotia cares about us the least.  So there is room for movement within back office positions, but if you want to transition to middle or front, this isn't a great place to start.

headline: Dismissed for trying to negotiate regarding the salary offer
pros: I can think of none.
cons:
1. Scotiabank does not reimburse you for hundreds of dollars in travel expenses incurred to come to the interviews.
2. They do not make even a small contribution to the expense of moving from a distant city.
3. They offer you a slightly lower salary than what they mention in the interview.
4. When you try to negotiate regarding the salary, they do not respond, but rather they make an offer to another candidate. So, Scotiabank offers the same position to two (or more) different candidates, a dishonest practice.
5. After making an offer, Scotiabank can come back to you later and say that the offer is rescinded, no discussion permitted, and that the position has been given to someone else. Whether or not you have already made plans to relocate or to quit your job or turned down other opportunities does not matter to Scotiabank.
6. Scotiabank does not offer pharmacy insurance to employees in the first year, even though the Ontario provincial insurance plan does not cover prescription medications, and it is standard in Ontario for a business, particularly a huge one like Scotiabank, to offer pharmacy insurance.
7. The salary that Scotiabank offers is well below market rates and those of its competitors.
8. Scotiabank's Human Resources bureaucracy seems to bungle things: for example, I received a notification that I had not been selected for a position weeks after I was selected for  that position.

headline: Former manager
pros:
Potential to rise up through the company very quickly if you work hard and have a supportive manager. 

Corporate culture is less competitive and cut-throat compared to the other banks. People work together to achieve goals. 

Starting to have a stronger focus on IT, so lots of potential for job seekers with IT background.
cons:
Pay is lower, compared to the other major Canadian banks. 

Having worked in three different divisions, your experience varies greatly depending on which area of the bank you work in. Very little consistency working between the divisions gives the impression that the company is not united. 

Company is also going through a lot of change (eliminating many top executives) and the environment is that your team could easily be moved or eliminated at any time.

headline: Worst Employer in My Life
pros: Most ordinary colleagues, excluding management, are helpful and supportive.
cons: Unrealistic sales goals without any account for a strength of your local market. Very old-school management systems. Fear-driven culture where asking questions or raising concerns about soundness of some decisions is extremely frowned upon. Orders are imposed from the top and executed mindlessly throughout the chain. No constructive discussion is possible. Everybody is afraid to speak up. Poor job security for advisors, call centre and mid office. High stress. High turnover. Your success is entirely dependent on your superior. Extremely poor infrastructure. Inefficient workflows. Customers are not the priority. Very stingy on the incentives. $150 bonus to the top credit card seller in a quarter sounds like an insult. Too many lies are floating around.
