headline: Investment Product Development
pros: Nice parties. Good discounts for employees in many stores.
cons:
Payment is below average. People like to wash their hands. Only brown nosers have success in Scotiabank. There are many incompetent VPs and Directors.
Leadership is inexistent in many areas. Everybody sees their own interest.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
Managers are very friendly and helpful. Very supportive in helping out when you need advice or help. Able to work at the other branches after your training is done, giving you more hours.
Potential to move up.
cons: A lot to learn and retain.

headline: Solutions Architect
pros: Changing culture in IT to AGILE methodologies
cons: internal processes have not caught up to the pace of change

headline: Underpaid and Overworked
pros: Product exposure and good location
cons: Too many politics, poor pay, outdated processes

headline: Not a place for people seeking work-life balance
pros: Demanding pace preps you to handle anything future employers will throw at you.
cons: Recent CEO transition has seen the Bank culture shift from overanalyzing lifers to corporate rowers expected to answer the bell at any time. The company still forces unpaid overtime and the poor economy and recent slew of layoffs has created a culture of fear rather than a culture of competition. Job stability is non existent and it is difficult to progress career-wise unless you are an insider. Cronyism runs rampant, but don't take my word for it, research the diversity of corporate senior leadership and judge for yourself.

headline: CUSTOMER SERVICE SUPERVISOR
pros: Scotiabank has a strong company culture, a supportive management team, and the retail branch is a relatively low stress environment.
cons: In the retail banking environment, the pay is average to low, and I didn't feel like it reflected my level of post-secondary education. The role was not very challenging.

headline: Awesome
pros: The work culture is very very laid back and easy for me.  The branch managers are very nice and precise.
cons: Working at a very very busy branch, so when its during busy hours it can get extremely tiring and exhausting.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Great training and overall experience
cons: redundant training at some points

headline: Scotiabank Strategy Group
pros: Good team, good culture and friendly co-workers
cons: hierarchy and too many controls

headline: Customer Service Supervisor
pros: no advantage just a survival job. very unprofessional
cons:
low pay 
Management retaliation being tolerated against employees

headline: Scotiabank
pros: People are great and willing to offer help
cons: Management seem like they were undereducated

headline: Was decent
pros: It was a good experience and the people there were rather helpful. Lots of room for promotion etc.
cons: With large companies, you get a lot of hierarchy and the sort. Sometimes it was hard to find who to talk to get something out.

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: Great experience and comfortable atmosphere to work in. The motivational level from employees/ers was amazing. There is opportunity to grow within the company.
cons: No cons. Absolute greatness within the branch.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Good experience working with the public, working on sales abilities, and learning the basics of retail banking
cons: Low pay, not many full-time positions

headline: Great company
pros: Great team, people and management
cons: Load of work non stop

headline: Senior Manager
pros: good growing opportunity , work life balance
cons: bonuses are low compared to other banks

headline: Mortgage Funding Officer
pros:
-entry level work experience
-learn to multi task, organize and prioritize
-good foot in the door into the mortgage industry
cons: -very stressful during summer months

headline: Senior invest advisor
pros: Defined pension plan is becoming more and more rare. Shared ownership program is also a great way to invest in/with the company. Lastly, co-workers are often a good support system
cons:
Work/life balance, inexperienced management, low pay, high turnover, and the list goes on...
It's quite unfortunate the way the bank and the industry as a whole has changed, but the fact of the matter is that financial advisors are not advisors at all. They are told to sell pretty much anything and everything regardless of the client's financial situation. Case in point: all clients are "supposed" to have a travel credit card, and a cash back card. Aren't most Canadians over indebted?!? isn't debt reduction a more important goal? Also,creditor insurance on most products is not only a complete waste, it's also very likely that it will never get paid out because the underwriting is done post-claim. Any advisor that sells balance insurance on a credit card is taking you for a ride. In terms of managers, there are very few good ones around. I've seen multiple coworkers break down in tears from the stress, training is sink or swim, computer systems are always crashing, pay is always below market reference, back-office support staff was phased out so now you're doing even more paperworker. I also question how a manager that has received a multitude of employee complaints, tanked a branch that was at the top of its district for years and seen a turnover of 90% of her sales team, can still manage to retain a job and be a leader. Very disappointing.

headline: Teller
pros: You can say you work at a bank, that's where it starts and ends for me personally. Reputable name for sure.
cons:
Serious pressure, beyond difficult to move up, as a teller you get a good wage. But it's 60/65 hour cheques. Over a standard full time job it works out to close to 11/hr. 
Never full time on teller unless have lots of experience.  .06 is 2nd highest position. Guarantees 22.5 hours - that means even if you work 33 hours a week and you take vacation. You're only paid 22.5. 
Management are on tight goals from head office so when you think you do something well - you won't be recognized - mores expected- it's never good enough

headline: Sr. PBO
pros: Lots of room for advancement, excellent people to work with
cons: Salary in the lows compared to other FIs, Expect a lot for the salary

headline: Full Time
pros: Respect for employees in every department
cons: office facilities need to be improved.

headline: Review
pros:
good culture
laid back environment
job security
no expectation of great performance
cons:
no expectation of great performance
salary low

headline: manager
pros: good stock option, standard hours
cons: some group's management is very poor

headline: just okay
pros: great people to work with
cons: the salary is very low

headline: MD
pros: Friendly work atmosphere, good reputation
cons: Bureaucratic, slow, risk averse, conservative

headline: 2201 eglinton contact centre sales the worse
pros: Unless you luck out and end up on a team with a seasoned manager or one that has balance there is no pros.
cons: The newer management in the sales department needs a complete over hall. Constructive criticism they like to give, but can't reciprocate.

headline: Friendly working environment
pros: Scotia bank is one of the most popular and 3rd largest bank in Canada. It is well known for its friendly working environment and good possibilities for professional growth.
cons: Scotia bank is a challenging place to work. I enjoyed the challenges and fast paced environment. Challenges give me the opportunity to enhance my skills and ability.

headline: Scotia
pros:
Good flexibility and work life balance
Respectful and often approachable senior management and leadership
Transitioning towards a stronger customer and performance orientation
cons:
Lack of congruence in development opportunity
Base pay not reflective of individual performance and very unparalleled amongst internal and externally acquired staff
Transitioning through different teams with vertical opportunities is often difficult

headline: Interesting experience. Great opportunity but average to below pay.
pros: Industry Leader, Financial Services, Community Involvement, Training opportunities, Vertical movement
cons: Average to below pay, long process from start to finish.

headline: an employer you should try to avoid.
pros: Absolutely none. Please refer to the Cons
cons: All is negative. Senior management doesn't have any management skills, salary is one third of my current compensation. Placement is wrong acceptance is totally wrong. It's a joke in my life.  Goodbye permanently.

headline: Customer Service
pros: Great work environment ! ! Very willing to help you with work and your career. I also had wonderful managers and co workers which made things great.
cons: I didn't have any cons to this job really. As an inter I just worked hard and they are very good to you.

headline: financial advisor
pros: Great management. Really looking to promote strong employees awareness of strengths and weaknesses of all staff members. Strong preformance as a top 5 bank very great oppurtunity to work for
cons: Very results orientated rather meaning high goals and focus on maximum profit rather then best experience for customer but overall expected based on competitors

headline: Not
pros: Nice coworkers and flexible hours for the csr. But if you want to work full time it will be almost impossible as a teller
cons: When looking to move, it depends on how accepting your boss is. They can scuttle your plans quickly. Promises but nothing else. They prefer to hire people with no background in banking, no experience instead to promote their own employees with experience. Bad management, they will push you to work hard, without giving you any tools or strategy. The bank is not what it used to be. Lots of unsatisfied employees, strangled by the management. The managers want just to move forward in their careers, running after bigger salaries, don't care about the employees who really work hard for small salaries. Too many changes, employees leaving the bank being unhappy and stressed out. In my branch, half of the old and experienced staff  quit because of the bad and new management. Not a peaceful, rewarded or beneficial for your health environment. Not to mention how many employees are on sick leave or burn out because of the stress.

headline: summer intern
pros: The company provided great learning curves, management was very helpful and patient with adjusting from school
cons: the company did not offer a hire back position even though they did not give me a reason why. they seemed pleased with my work ethic and tasks completed

headline: Financial advisor
pros: The experience is good for someone in their 20s. Get exposure to the banking and finance industry, lending, and some investment.
cons: Compensation is not the best. Average financial advisor at any bank in Canada makes a very average sales but the sales pressure is beyond the pay. Too much sales pressure as the banking industry is evolving.

headline: Co-op student
pros: Payment above the market, big learning, great networking
cons: Long working hours, no work life balance, difficult transition to full time employer

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros:
easy to learn 
system fairly easy to work with
cons: financial goals increase with every year.this com become stressfull

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Supportive upper management. Good teamwork
cons: I would say none cause the branch I worked for had a very good team of co-workers and managment

headline: Finance Analist
pros: Excellent benefits for their employees
cons: Few development opportunities, because senior management don't like training

headline: Good and bad
pros: Smart, hard-working colleagues, good career progression opportunities, fast learning curve, access to resources, access to management teams, learning about the markets, good total per-year compensation, challenging work, good to learn financial modelling and research writing, good to develop attention to detail
cons: Long hours, stressful, lack of team spirit, low compensation after-tax, per-hour, lack sufficient resources to do job well, not the most meaningful job in the world, work is often boring, repetitive and tedious, investment advice tends to be very short-term

headline: Good company overall, but could be better
pros: Good Culture, Great People, Relaxed atmosphere
cons: Technology, Feels like the company isn't run in a smart manner, Pay could be more competitive

headline: Senior Personal Banking Officer
pros: Good pay, training and banking benefits. Good for career development in banking field. Good work and life balance. Good for professional skills build-up.
cons: Management in branch level can be improved. It’s majorly a sales role associated with sales targets, so competition can be aggressive.

headline: Just ok
pros:
Great co-workers
Possibility of flex work hours
cons:
Training is lacking
Management is under-qualified
High workload

headline: Good Work Life Balance
pros:
Excellent work life balance
Great people
cons: Pace is a slower than competitors

headline: Not a place for high performers
pros: Good place for those who don't want to work hard
cons: Pay below average; not a high performing culture

headline: Great culture. Employees are very committed to company success
pros: Many employees have had multiple careers within one company. Tons of opportunity for growth including a great footprint in Latin America.
cons: Many of the workstations and facilities require a facelift to bring into current and new workplace standards. Great locations. Just need an upgrade.

headline: financial advisor
pros: multicultural working place, fairness
cons: sales pressure and no technology

headline: Standard Compensation
pros: Scotiabank like any other bank offers its employees the standard compensation package by matching stocks upto 50%, providing health and dental insurance, and vacation days based on number of years of experience.
cons: The insurance benefits have significantly decreased since the switch from GWL to Manulife. Also, change in CEO seems to have triggered a more money driven approach which resulted in employees paying the price by having a reduction in benefits, services, bonuses, perks etc.

headline: Sales and Trading Summer Analyst
pros: Very chill group. Hours were great -- 7 till 5. Not too much difficult work and very consistent day to day
cons: Kind of boring program. Don't really get to push yourself. No formal training of any kind. Also was for the entire summer whereas most programs run only 10 weeks. Pay was weak

headline: Director and Group Lead
pros: Friendly people and collegial environment. Flex days for personal benefit.  Work life balance.
cons: Dated corporate culture. Poorly articulated strategy at the senior commercial leadership level. Limited training provided. Lack industry appropriate compensation. Poor morale. Poor communication. Risk culture is so conservative so it's difficult to get deals done. Painful credit process.

headline: Scotiabank Full-time employee
pros:
- Colleagues were very patient and helpful
- You will learn a lot about the banking business and organizational structure
- Salary was very generous
- Nice corporate culture
cons:
- Typical office politics and talking behind people's backs
- Some of their processes could be improved (felt outdated)

headline: Employee Engagement
pros: The only employees engaged were those at the VP+ levels.
cons: The Bank is undergoing restructures and they have laid off many employees.  The problem is that the work is then channeled to the employees that are left behind.  This is a toxic environment.

headline: Scotiabank - Equity Research Associate
pros:
- Caring, accommodating culture (HR perspective)
- Strong in-bank development opportunities
- Great opportunity to learn sector and financial fundamentals
- Predictably busy
cons:
- Lower-than-average to average comp vs. the street
- Work/life balance is an issue (nature of the job)
- Very little thought leadership at the associate level (nature of the job)

headline: Sr. Financial Advisor
pros: Large employer, stable job. Some people work a whole life there.
cons: promotion is mostly in retail banking if you are not in Toronto

headline: Recruitment
pros: Great team, flexible work hours!
cons: At times the role could be very administrative, taking away the focus from actually being able to recruit.

headline: Director
pros: Financial Services is a dynamic Industry. Scotiabank offers a unique opportunity in Canada as it is a global bank. Opportunities to learn a multitude of skills in many different countries with Scotiabank.
cons: Financial Services are traditional companies moving to compete in a nimble digital world. This has increased the workload, reduced the recognition and increased the stress which has implications on productivity.

headline: CSO
pros: Great and friendly environment, 3 months of training and benefits. Room for growth after 18 months of being on the floor. Great mangement.
cons: Hard to get full time hours. The metrics that are in place do not take into account a lot of factors that effect the call resolution

headline: interviews
pros: No room for administrative jobs or advancement
cons: more beneficial thing to offer employees plus cheaper benefits

headline: Financial Advisor
pros:
Good pay for a first career job
Good learning experience
Strong brand name
cons:
High sales goals
Lack of support
A lot of redundant policies and procedures
Outdated systems
Scotia is a last to move company

headline: Job Security is now a pipedream. Welcome to the era of Mr. Burns
pros: Decent vacation. Hours are respectable.
cons:
In the era of cost cutting, forget about joining Scotiabank if you want a company that supports you financially for education. 

Don't join this bank unless you're ready to accept a reality of seeing peers drop like flies. This will be a norm. Regulatory pressure + lower market share = less profits = lower headcount. 

Leadership...hmm. "Senior" Executives (pun intended) who have no background in emerging technologies throwing "fintech" buzzwords around. Sorry guys, a trip to silicon valley doesn't make you Jeff Bezos.

headline: Human Resources
pros: A lot of great people work at Scotiabank. They are willing to help and the culture breeds teamwork. The company is going through a lot of changes to recruitment functions and processes which is a good thing.
cons: There needs to be a better sense of project management. Currently too many levels of approvals are needed to get things accomplished. This isn't strange for such a large organization

headline: CSR
pros: Decent starting pay, career growth within company was promoted, training was thorough
cons: poor management, branch manager expected CSRs to perform sales pitches meant for Financial Advisors

headline: Great place to work
pros: Excellent trainee programs and employee development plan
cons: Nothing to say at the moment

headline: Solid global bank with great traditions
pros: Scotiabank is a solid global bank with 190-year history and good reputation. Many people have worked for 30-40 years here. Low employee departure rate. The Work-life balance is better than at other comparable institutions.
cons: If you work well, your career may stall just because your leaders are happy having you in your role.  In Canada, the bank pays less than competitors.  In the U.S. - mid-market.

headline: Job Security but not perhaps not career advancement
pros: There are lots of hours available for those who want to work
cons: Very low compensation for tellers. Little encouragement for promotion for entry level positions.

headline: Programmer Analyst
pros: Great work variety, you won't be stuck doing repetitious tasks. Good location, conveniences nearby. Good people staffing various work departments.
cons: Work pressure and tight timelines can occasionally lead to critical timelines. Some existing systems especially legacy systems are either poorly documented or the documentation is difficult to find. Can be frustrating.

headline: Enterprise Risk
pros:
Great Company to work for. Generally speaking the benefits, pension and salary are all comparable to industry standards. Lots of ways to take educational leaves and progress your skill set. 

The risk department is top heavy which is nice.
cons:
Extremely hierarchical. 

Its a grind because its a lot of work. That said, this is what you signed up for.

headline: financial advisor
pros: Good compensation and good  benefits
cons: Pressure and deadlines can be stressful

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great and friendly work environment. Great support from superiors.
cons: Upward mobility seems more slow-paced than one would like.

headline: Small team
pros: Great manager - approachable, resourceful, great mentor
cons: Pay is relatively low, very little employee perks

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Co-workers were generally the best part about being in branch, caring and helpful majority of time.
cons: Management tried to tie you down to role, didn't get much opportunity for advancement unless it was in the best interests of higher ups.

headline: Bank is evolving from " great work environment" to "what did you sell today" under the guise of being customer centric.
pros: Some great people to work with and systems improving. Pay in line with other banks. They promote learning and want you to have a career not just a job
cons: Change implemented too often, too fast with unrealizable expectations. Branch environment is becoming toxic with very high expectations for all sales officers and service providers  with minimal support from management. Moving support/call centers to Ontario not well received by staff

headline: Love it!
pros: Great environment. People are friendly, helpful and fun to be around.  There is always something to do and the salary is good to.
cons: Keeping up the commitment to great customer service. Especially in tuff situations. But its to be expected in a service oriented business.

headline: Cheap and Unorganized
pros: Standard Canadian bank, not much different than anywhere else. Nothing particularly great about this bank compared to others I have worked in.
cons: Pay is less than peers and benefits are poor. Company is very disorganized.

headline: I was expecting more
pros: Great life & work balance
cons: I think that the directors are not that great. They tent to control every single thing.

headline: Disappointed
pros: Great culture. Lots of exposure. I love the client meetings. Lots of coaching.
cons: Selling credit and insurance is the worst. Otherwise can't complain.

headline: Bad management style in the branches. Overall company has a good plan but its not being applied by lower management.
pros: Good environment and welcoming. Most people that work here have a good attitude towards others. A lot of diversity when it comes to job offerings because of it being an international company.
cons: Hard work is not rewarded or appreciated, lower level management is bad 80% of the time. Corporate mindset that is strict and rigid.

headline: Fair Employee Benefits
pros: Flexible and friendly working environment with good career development opportunities.
cons: Just ok employee benefit package with lower end parental leave policy among peers and other benefits. Paying fairly low salary comparing to other banks.

headline: Good Company
pros: Good place to work, lots of opportunities
cons: I can not think of any

headline: Assistant Manager
pros: The employees of Scotiabank make it a great place to work. Room to advance and progress in the retail banking world if that is your career of choice.
cons: More opportunities in Toronto for growth and a variety of positions, not so much in the west. Sad to see the direction the bank is going.

headline: Underpaid and underappreciated
pros: Stability and job security, employee shares
cons: You will be underpaid for what you do

headline: Great bank!
pros:
- Supportive managers and VPs 
- Encourages further development and learning
cons: - Pay increase is gradual

headline: A generally good employer
pros: A very diverse employer; provides good coaching and and generally stable work environment.
cons: I've seen some of the most talented workers stuck in a contract position for years. Fix this. Also it's all about who you know in the company.

headline: Report and Data Analyst
pros: Big company. Many opportunities at the bank
cons: Work environment is not good with abusive peers.

headline: formerly paternalistic firm in transition
pros:
- great people, collegial culture, easy to get help from others in the firm (people, even executives, almost always respond)
- traditionally conservative and risk-averse environment (the anti-Lehman...)
cons:
- rapid changes are underway which appear to be causing unintended consequences -- proceed with caution, although the culture change might benefit you
- traditionally poor compensation has led to complacency and often poor morale (and mediocre middle management and junior execs)

headline: Portfolio Admin
pros: Helpful team. Easing going working environment
cons: Salary is below market standard

headline: Credit Solutions Analyst
pros: Great job for someone right out of school
cons: Not a client facing role

headline: 3 Years Experience at Scotia
pros: Great diversity and collaboration among internal partners both in Canada and internationally. Fun people to work with. Good balance.
cons: Very slow moving and risk averse. The change in leadership recently has led to a fair level of disruption at all levels but this should be a long term positive.

headline: It use to be a good place to work. I guess now the times are hard for everyone.
pros: Stable work place. They never lay off people.
cons: Very limited opportunity to grow. They cut down all the bonuses and benefits. Very stressful. There is no flexibility at all.

headline: Senior Financial Advisor
pros: If you work near your branch, it can be a reasonable commute.
cons: Training program is horrible. Pay is very poor, benefits expensive. Management always demanding more sales even if you reach your targets. Never satisfied. Recently changed pension so that if I don't leave by 2018, I can't take it as a lump sum. Don't think I will be there that long.

headline: Customer Service Officer
pros: Decent pay/benefits. Good location and opportunities.
cons: Toxic work environment. Micromanaging managers.

headline: Mortgage Underwriter
pros: Over the past 10 years I've worked with some amazing people. Loved my job, even on 'bad' days. Always enjoyed the challenge of bringing in more business and loved working with HFA's & Brokers to successfully approve mortgages for clients.
cons: Severe and rapid downsizing taking place. Over 500 people laid off (or due to be laid off in near future) and that's just at the Western Service Centre in Calgary. Less than 3 months ago we were reassured our jobs were secure and didn't need to be concerned.....then last week they closed the Mortgage unit and previously the Calgary contact centre They lied to us and misled us -  so many broken promises! Scotiabank is not to be trusted, they do not care about the people - no apologies & no appreciation. Stay away from Scotiabank, the focus is global expansion - even when you call the customer service line, chances are you'll be connected to South America.

headline: Worst ceo ever
pros: Nothing after the departure of Mr.Rick Vaugh
cons: Unstable company lot of change ahead with a ceo brian porter who thinks he is harry potter wants to make scotia becoming 1st in canadian banking. He is dreaming in black and white. He is outsourcing everything to third world countries depriving canadians of jobs for profit sake. He is like the type ready to sell his soul to the devil in order to become number in the canadian market puting every reason on only Customer satisfaction. Scotiabank was recognised for caring for its employees under the 'ruling' of Mr.Rick Vaugh which is the one he will never fit his shoes. The new little apprentice ceo approved fired a lot of people across canada recently halifax calgary vancouver etc... He doesn't care about employees they are just ladders and minions for profits.

headline: Decent
pros: Easy work, not much to it, good for students, learned a lot about mortgages
cons: Upper management can be snobby, not very open to change, I would not work there another summer

headline: Team work culture
pros: Excellent corporate culture, team work, professional growth
cons: Burocracy, salary is not competitive compared with the industry, work-life balance,

headline: Senior System Support Specialist
pros: Great place to work.    Very strong in social responsibility.
cons: Lower pay compare to other Banking industry.    Not much opportunity to growth.

headline: Retail Banking Officer
pros: Perform well and adhere to management's advice, you will see yourself moving up!
cons: Monotonous and repetitive work procedures.

headline: Great workplace, conservative pay
pros: Good environment, been lucky to have helpful, caring supervisors (four in eight years over different departments). Annual program to give your thoughts on your manager, department and the bank overall. Has been apparent effort in the past to act on survey results.
cons: Salary is on conservative side of industry average. Many employees at all levels who have been with bank for many, many years, reducing advancement opportunities somewhat. Possible conflicts of seniority entitlement versus real performance, however, have experienced very little of that. Larger alignment with industry and emphasis on performance and efficiency seen with change of CEO and cost cutting measures.

headline: Excellence
pros: Treated like family. Enjoy the client relationships
cons: Going through some major changes within the system. Good changes but many at one time. Keeping up is sometimes difficult

headline: Scotia Bank
pros: I have been with Scotia bank for 28 years and cannot think of one negative thing to say about the company. It's great to work for an organization that treats its employees with respect and fosters an environment of inclusion. Scotia bank has a wonderful employee recognition program and employees who are truly dedicated to helping customers and make a honest effort to do their best are greatly rewarded.
cons: I cant think of any

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Job security, Easy system ,strong Canadian company .
cons: Prtnership between employees effective only between employess that are there for years ..night between all ...Salary not reasonable for those who work hard ...long term employees can live a peaceful life just being  order takers new will leave looking at the struggle in getting business  ...partnership and segmentation improper and ineffective. .

headline: Proud to be a Scotiabanker!
pros:
International exposure 
Focused on providing the best customer experience 
Dynamic and fast passed 
Strong culture and values 
Supporters of employees development
cons: Compensation and benefits are not the highest between the banks but aren't the lowest neither

headline: Call redirect - specialized investments
pros: Absolutely amazing workplace! Management takes big initiative in career development and opportunities are endless! You can request to job shadow any department you are interested in or looking forward to developing your career in.
cons: There are very minimal downsides in my opinion. It is a challenge to find parking if you are working later shifts.

headline: Better Salary
pros: Always give back to the community
cons: Overall benefits are good. However, would a higher monthly salary would be nice

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Team player environment
Great benefits
Stress free
cons: Rather than having HR do the hiring, give management the opportunity to meet with recipients applying for employment

headline: Great organization and employer
pros: Excellent employee. Great opportunities for those that are goal oriented and customer focused. Truly an environment of talented individuals.
cons: Undergoing transition. For anyone that needs consistency...status quo, this is the wrong environment.

headline: Awesome then terrible
pros: Good salary. A new district Vice President came to Vancouver island and changed the culture from customer to sales focused. Before her, Scotiabank empowered bankers to solve financial problems for clients while yes, trying to cross sell products. Now it's all sales
cons: So sales focused you are pressured to sell every client 4 credit cards. So sales focused if a client has too many products with Scotia or little money you are not to deal with them, in not so many words... No performance management. If you sell you might get promoted. If you build relationships and sell what makes sense you'll be performances managed out of Scotia.

headline: Scotiabank
pros: I have worked fie Scotiabank  for 21 years and it's a great  company. ..great values and good to employees. ..good benifits
cons: Salary should be higher  as everthing  goes up and salary  doesn't

headline: Customer service supervisor.
pros: Great hours. Nice benefits. Fantastic customers. Love my coworkers.
cons: Not always great communication or proper training.

headline: Great employer
pros: great place to work. Excellent community involvement, no pay inequality between genders or race. Good benefits.
cons: Unfortunately the salaries are on the low side of competitive. The pension plan could be a little better.

headline: Costumer relation representative
pros: Best place to work with full benefit and lots opportunities for future
cons: Not applicable for downsides Best place to work with full benefit and lots opportunities for future

headline: Customer service
pros: Its been 8 beautiful months that I am working with scotia bank. The 1st bank I saw when I landed in canada and fell in love with was scotia plaza and now am proud to be a part of the team
cons:
as of now no cons🙈
Company is treating me good

headline: CSO- customer service officer contact center
pros: The culture is amazing. We genuinely care for eachother and have fun together.  I love the people that surround me.
cons:
Their technology makes it so you can't do your job properly more often then it ever should. When issues that are causing customers to call in upset and leave the bank are not resolved with in 2 years it's bad. Also they focus so much on the customer they forget to focus on the employees happiness as well. Both are needed for success. 
They invest money in things that the outside world can see instead of fixing things that would actually create a better customer experience and their employees would be able to actually do their jobs.

headline: Financial Advisor Level 4
pros: Discount off your banking.  Scene points.  Lots of facilities around if you move can transfer your job.
cons: Company does not have your back.  Treats you poorly and never on your side.  After reporting management mistreating me nothing was done.

headline: Bad investment!
pros: Great people to meet. A very diverse culture. That's about it.
cons: No job security. They take advantage of eagerness to learn and inexperience of new bees. Very low work life balance. Managers don't take ownership or communicate.

headline: Customer service representative
pros: Scotiabank is a family, I spend more time with them then my own, and live every minute if it. When I became pregnant they threw me a shower :)
cons: There is no downside, if I had to critique anything it would be the fact there aren't any positions for full-time tellers, only part time.

headline: Bilingual Customer Service Officer
pros: Flexible, consistent assistance, amazing customers, great pay, bonuses, incentives, innovative
cons: Work holidays, consistent change

headline: Clueless management
pros: They will promote you quickly if you are good at your job
cons: Pay is low, they treat staff poorly. Turnover at our branch is extremely high because management does not know how to treat people. They will blame you for mistakes that they make.

headline: Financial Advisor 5
pros: some of my co-workers create a great work environment.
cons: expectations greatly exceed compensation. Small town branches with large client base where we know our customers and they don't like getting called by a stranger at the contact centre to discuss their finances

headline: financial advisor
pros: good environment and workplace for those who plan on advancing in branch
cons: pay is low… benefits are not as good as other banks.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros: Good environment, great support, nice colleagues
cons: Nothing much really. Salary can be improved

headline: Senior Management
pros: Great people. Culture. Diversity of work and opportunities
cons: Lots of Managers, not enough leaders,  lack of direction from Management, silo-ed approach,

headline: Not bad
pros: Great people in this organization
cons: Bad pay compared to the industry

headline: Scotiabank Financial Advisor 6
pros: Not sure right now with the way things are going...
cons: The culture has taken a serious downhill slide.  Employee morale is the worst I've seen in my 10 years there as we shift from 'doing what's right for the customer' to making everything all about sales and numbers, even if it doesn't make sense.  The 'performance mindset' they want you to have tells you to not care about family, the value of people, and doing what's right for clients.  The amount of micro-managing, observational coaching, and useless meetings is mind boggling.

headline: Marketing Manager
pros: Scotiabank is a great place to work, with a work life balance and good corporate culture. There are a lot of opportunity for career development and improving your skills.
cons: Lack of cross-department or group knowledge exchange or mentoring. In some cases you have to seek it out.

headline: coop analyst
pros: Good working environment. People are friendly. I have a chance to access multiple interesting projects.
cons: The salary is low and workload is high.

headline: ok
pros: ok place to work, friendly people although not the best performers
cons: not very organized always starting from 0

headline: Canada
pros: good culture, many job opportunities, community involvement, extensive training in some positions
cons: Health benefits, change management, dated performance management

headline: Banking Customer Service
pros: Great work environment, lots of career opportunities, great salary
cons: None that I could think of

headline: Great work culture

headline: Okay

headline: Review

cons: Worst compensation of BIG 5 Canadian banks. Senior management has also undergone a huge change which has been terrible for morale.

headline: Financial service trainee
pros: good company for improvement in your field

headline: Customer Support Representative

headline: Tremendous banking school
pros: Highly developed banking standards. International environment to work in. Variety of opportunities to develop a long carreer. Competitive salaries.

headline: Great place to work!

headline: Part-time Customer Service Experience
pros: It is a very nice environment to work for. Colleagues can be very nice.
cons: I feel that the branch can be under a lot of pressure from head office. As a result, some branches forget to nurture the career aspirations of their employees.

headline: Financial advisor

headline: Financial Analyst

headline: customer service representative

headline: teller

a lot of gray area.
for some its like having family business

headline: Best Company Yet!

Coworkers

headline: Customer Service Representative

cons: Amalgamation of jobs to help corporate office save more money. You'll have to learn someone else's job before their position is eliminated. Not to say that they won't be taken care of (they're good for that) but you can expect a steady work load of new information and job tasks.

headline: Scotiabank Mexico
pros: Adequate job benefits, such as health care and insurance, personal loans, mortgage loans, access to diverse sportive clubs. Active participation in social and environmental issues. Good remuneration level in high management.
cons: Focus on hours spent in work, lack of talent development and acknowledgment. Excessive internal bureaucracy and lack of empowerment from high directives to the lower organizational structure. Low remuneration level in mid and low management.

headline: No career advancement opportunity
pros: No pros: or maybe very friendly co workers. Company benefit is ridiculous and all people with potential left. Not recommend
cons: Turn over is sky high, no learning opportunity, manager cares about sales only. Overtime all the time and the company can't retain good staff l

headline: SBA
pros: Stable, regular hours, predictable, challenging

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Scotiabank has a collaborative culture. And once you are in, there is high likelihood you will be invited back.
cons: There are many layers of management at Scotiabank. So as a young student, you might shy away from the complicated structure.

headline: Manager lvl 7
pros: Lots of talented people that share the same vision. Good pension benefits and good stock option benefits. Lot of collaboration between business lines when a common goal is shared. Good compensation package (Bonus).
cons: Senior management sometimes can be cryptic; though not in all departments. Salary compensation could be better; IE someone that's been in the same role as I have but only 1 year (I have been for 3) makes slightly more than I do.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Friendly work environment, networking skills
cons: Short staffed, doing more than you're getting paid for.

headline: Good, but can do better

cons: Low pay, not too many opportunities. The perks are just not what you get at some of these other companies, especially in the tech community.

headline: Inventor
pros: They have the best tools and the best people. If you stay long enough, you may feel like they are your family. It is very competitive in a healthy way. The team loves what it does and it will make you love it, too. There is a lot of love and overwhelming friendship. I have tears in my eyes just thinking about the workplace and the team and the technology oh my God.
cons: It can be very challenging, especially if you get involved with members of the team because it is hard to be so enthusiastic about your job and receive criticism from insiders. If you like Mercedes Benz, run away, this company will not welcome you.

headline: Assosciate Program Analyst
pros: Good working environment. Like it.
cons: Process oriented. So be ready.

headline: financial advisor
pros: no goals the first six months of training, managers an colleagues always approachable and helpful, friendly environment
cons: Scotia offers a low pay, overwork employees, long hours, cheap benefits. Emphasis on the lowest salary from all financial institutions

headline: It contractor
pros: Good work environment! Good job

headline: Anonymous employee review
pros: Big organization and international so possibility of moving around. Opportunities are available, you just have to look for them.
cons: IT moves at a sloths pace. Older systems, old processes. Benefits package is not very competitive.

headline: 21st century bank
pros: Conservative culture undergoing change. Lots of flexibility in job role. Opportunity exists inside the bank if you want to climb.
cons: Morale is sometimes poor. Salaries are on the low end. People who do not perform (and don't care) are left in positions for way too long. Serious divide between credit culture and sales culture.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Great overall package (salary, bonus, vacation, stock options, free banking etc), there is an employee  recognition program whereby you can "cash in" to extra bonuses like gift cards and an annual "set of the Best for a chance to win a trip, culture is changing in a good way under Brian Porter to be more performance oriented and more accountable which rewards people who work smart. They are putting very smart leadership in place.
I think it is one of the best employers in Canada.
cons: Change takes a long time

headline: Especialist

management are disconected with battle field

Below industry compensation

headline: Associate

headline: so far so good

headline: Customer Representative

headline: Personal Banking Office
pros: Good Stepping stone. Colleagues are helpful. Male managers are really helpful.
cons: A lot. Old school ladies managers stuffed with eggo and surrounded by bunch of jokers who is ready to do even household stuff !! (yes that's true)to get promotion or reccomendation. My friend just left (842) and I am just waiting to ring the bell. How do you work when you have these people throwing you off the day everyday. They become very helpful in morning huddle and camoflague but as soon as it ends they throw the mask away.

headline: Sr Assistant Manager

Very comfortable work atmosphere.

headline: Good opportunity, poor pay

cons: Initial salaries are below average to the marketplace. Management can severely impact performance ratings and pay improvement negatively. Benefits are also poor.

headline: Great people in a large company with lots of opportunities.
pros: Large company with lots of varied career options. Excellent collaborative people at the Director and below level. Excellent customer service and pride at the Branch level.
cons: Highly politicized at the VP+ level. Slow to adopt change. Few formal processes (constant wheel-reinventing). Some less than ideal work locations.

headline: Great time, no regrets
pros: Strong corporate culture, and great people to work with. With an older group of employees it is a great time to jump on as promotions are very realistic.
cons: In the end it is a bank and they can move really slowly. Not fast enough for me to develop back end software to aid with business developments.

headline: Good and bad
pros: Friendly workplace, nice diversity within its workforce both culturally and spiritually.
cons: Benefits package are not as comparable as other big banks in Canada. Do not allow new employees to contribute to corporate share plan until after 1 year of service. Health care benefit provider is terrible and create too much red tape and prevent employees to access needed assistance.

rude management
unrealistic expectations
too much politics

great culture.

headline: On your own

headline: Manager

headline: VP - Business Deposits
pros: World Class Bank with large International presence
cons: Declining US in the US market

headline: A long-standing, conservative organization undergoing major cultural change
pros: Scotiabank actively promotes employees taking risks with their carreers and get to try new things, be it different functional roles or moving through the international markets in which it operates.
cons: The pay generally lags peers. It used to be compensated with job stability but with the increasingly meritocracy based culture (which is the right model to shift to) those gaps have yet to be closed.

headline: Senior PBO
pros: I can't think of any pros. The pay is not stellar, the benefits are sub-par compare to other Big 4 banks. If you like structured work routine, then the branch sales job would be ideal for you.
cons:
- PBO/Sr PBO (now they are called Financial Advisor 4,5,6) are purely sales job at the branch. The job requires you to sell every single Scotiabank products to all customers. There are times I sold products that the customers do not need but I did it because I need to hit my target.
- With the current SRD structure, more un-necessary products will be offered to customers for the sake of meeting personal target.
- Favouritism is huge in the retail branch level. A lot of people who are qualified for the job do not get the promotion because majority of the time, the position is already hand picked by the hiring manager or district VP. 
- If you try to apply for a job posting outside the branch world (ie: Corporate head office), it is not impossible but very hard. It would be easier to get the job as a non-Scotiabank employee than current employee.

headline: analyst
pros: culturally diverse environment with good work life balance.
cons: salary is less compared to other financial institutions. management needs proper direction.

headline: Great place to learn
pros: Great processes in place, fee-free bank accounts and credit cards.
cons: Shortage of resources but the amount of work is enormous. As a result each employee is overburdened. Below average benefits. Backward in technology compred with other banks.

headline: Needs work at the Mid-Management level
pros:
- Large organization, Top 5 banks in Canada
- Various functions in both Canadian and International Banking
- Strong brand, everyone knows what it stands for
cons:
- Culture is overly collegial
- Reward and recognition is lacking
- A lot of long-term Scotiabankers are stuck in old ways and holding the organization back from advancing

headline: FA job review

cons: There are a lot of changes you need to keep up with, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, it just means you have to do your reading! You also need to be able to budget your time well to fit in what is expected of you. Sometimes the pay doesn't exactly feel like it is compensating for all the work you're doing.

headline: Decent job

cons: Not enough flexibility, very old school approach, old technology

headline: good

headline: Good Employer

cons: No cons to report it is a typicall bank environment.

headline: Feels like high school, round 2
pros:
Fantastic people. The only thing that kept me there were my colleagues.
The work itself was easy as long as you're comfortable talking to people.
cons:
Work/life balance was a promise made straight out of the gate, wasn't a reality until 2 months before they decided to close the contact centre. Incentives were promised, but hard to obtain and only came around once a year.
Every coaching session, team meeting and corporate policy change was dressed up and 'dumbed' down to a point where they were just using pictures to get the point across.  
If you felt like high school was the high point of your life... Scotiabank is the place for you.

headline: Scotiabank
pros: Lots of support and growth potential
cons: Can be hard to stay creative

headline: Great company
pros: A world of opportunity here.

headline: Slow and steady

cons: Scotia is slow to adopt new technologies and methodologies.   They are stuck using old programming languages because of the necessary support for the legacy systems.

Fair income

headline: financial advisor

headline: Like high school...

Lots of hours 
Great benefits sick leave and ect

Access to things needed at home

Like high school... If your part of in crowd you move up!

headline: Sales team - Inbound/Outbound
pros:
- Great people and friendly work environment. This is basically the main reason why I stayed here for so long and still harbor hope for a better future with this company. 
- People here are very helpful and actually take time for their team mates, if you're lucky enough to find a good team.
- Management is generally more caring than most places. They understand if you're late from time to time or if you are just having a bad day. It is very relaxed here.
cons:
- It is a political minefield here. Everywhere you step, something will go boom. You cannot trust anyone here as everyone will probably have an ulterior motive. 
- Development is completely in your own hands. If you want to move up, be ready to do all the dirty work yourself. Don't count on any help or guidance from the management team.
- Expectations for numbers is very high however, they sugar coat it. "Numbers don't matter as long as you are following the Call Flow Model". At the end of the day, this is BS. Numbers do matter as only those who hit all the targets get the higher rating, and hence higher bonus and more opportunity to advance their career. 
- There is no flexibility with your shifts or much of work life balance. You don't have much choice. New people are more than likely stuck in the 3-11pm Tuesday to Sat shift, and that would probably not change until they change jobs or something.

headline: You start off as part time and within a yr get full time hours
pros: Pretty laid back environment. Has comfortable chairs in the "quiet room". Free parking.  Friendly coworkers. Management will hear your suggestions. May not respond to you but it's nice that they listen I guess
cons: The pay sucks. Opportunity to grow is limited. Management will blame employees rather than look at it's current process to improve customer satisfaction. Employee satisfaction and morale is constantly low

headline: Manager, Campaign Execution

Great environment, excellent team members
Wide array of opportunities between departments
cons: Required to stay in the position for 3 years before exploring other opportunities

headline: Financial Advisor

headline: Customer Service Officer
pros: friendly and diverse group of co-workers
cons: The supervisor who conducted my f2f interview in their Hfx call centre was 20 minutes late. The job description doesn't explain that call centre employees are expected to be technical support workers in resolving customer complaints about the corporate website. Telephone employees also schedule appointments for staff at branches right across the country. Employees are squeezed for every ounce of productivity. The mantra is do more in less time. 16.25 an hour to be secretaries, tech support and jack of all trade phone support

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: work life balance, peaceful work,  respect for all, lot of independence, I love this company. no words to explain.

headline: Senior Manager

It's SO hard for those of us that are because most of your team is eating donuts and on Facebook. So glad the CEO demanded cuts. Another poster is right, if the staff we had was qualified we wouldn't need half the people in any department.

headline: Atmosphere
pros: Friendly staff, we have a great rapport. Great atmosphere to work in. Not such a bad place to go to every day.
cons: older staff refusing to change with new policies, makes it hard when you are trying to follow the rules. Management keeps giving you more to do..... Do your job, but also make reminder calls for the the office people, sell product....sell more product. You start feeling like you're getting berried in work that isn't even yours.

headline: Not the best place to work
pros: The coworkers made it great. NOT the company. I had good managers.
cons:
Even for a corporate structure, it was rigid beyond reason. My dept. had a very good manager for 10 years. Once she left, the dept. hit the gutter. Almost the entire staff roster has been replaced from people quitting and fed up with how terrible the system is.

The computer hardware is truly embarassing for a bank that claims it wants to stay relevant with technology. I am not even exaggerating.

The pay is pretty low.

headline: Not a great experience
pros: There is good morale among employees.
cons: Management is in Canada and has a poor sense of direction

headline: Nice place to work
pros:
Friendly, Lots of opportunities, great place to work overall.
It is a place that emanates Stability, very reliable. Management is concerned about each employee on a personal level.
cons: Low salary comparing with other Banks. To be underpaid is the only great problem I see at Scotiabank. besides that, all the other aspects are pretty positive,

headline: General Review
pros: Great place to work, enjoy it very much
cons: None that i can think of

headline: Opportunity
pros: Strong culture of promoting from within. If you perform, management will back you, and work with you to get you to the next level.
cons: As is the case with any job, the workload can be demanding if you are not organized, and do not stay on top of your agenda.

headline: Scotiabank review
pros: great work culture, support to move through up in the company
cons: need better ways to communicate department wide

headline: Not for me
pros: comfortable work place, job security,
cons: very high sales targets, indifferent upper management, lack of compensation, High stress sales environment.

headline: Scotia Review
pros: Staff benefits are great, the work environment is welcoming.
cons: a bit slow on advancing the banking system by using technology.

headline: customer service representative

headline: Worse than jail

cons:
Poor management and work culture, unacceptable pay.
10 days annual leave, and over 60% of colleagues are waiting for retirement.
Too much office politics.

headline: Great place to work

headline: sales support

headline: Scotiabank
pros: good work life balance, good people

headline: Decent place to learn
pros: For the most part, relaxed work environment compared to other banks. Teams are generally lean so opportunity to get broad exposure on transactions.
cons: Lack of structured personal development opportunities. Few similar-aged employees. Scotia feels "cheap" in several ways compared to competitors.

headline: Excellent Employer
pros: Various opportunities to gain the experience you want, strong culture, if you put int he work you will be recognized, talented individuals
cons: Must be open to being mobile, large financial institution is not suitable for all

easy interview
nice environment, nice management. flexible hours

parking space shortage.

not a lot internal postings

cons:
- Outdated technology (Late 90's)

- Compensation and benefits are lacking

headline: Financial Advisor 4
pros: Great coworkers, excellent hours and no weekends. Advancement opportunities are there if your willing to move
cons: Pay is to little for the amount of work you do. Computers are outdated and slow. Monitor too small customers always saying wow that's small.  We need printers in our office

headline: excellent opportunity

headline: business analyst
pros: You can learn a lot of new business knowledge, various business products, computer software. Have some fantastic business events and activities to join. Free coffee and tea.
cons: tight  and strict regulation and rules. management team is not very nice. work environment is not good. Workplace is very open, no privacy at all. No freedom, cannot have your opinion. If you want to be a good worker, then just follow your manager's expectation.

Friendly staff
work life balance
work 8 am to 4 pm
cons:
pay less than market reference
do not invest in employee training programs - once a year may be
not much growth in the IT audit dept as ppl are working from 20 years

headline: Teller
pros: Great place to work at
cons: Some bad things about the job

headline: Best Job I Ever Had
pros: Company culture, free lunches, sabbaticals.
cons: Cubicle environment, can't use social media at work.

headline: Senior manager
pros: great work place and every one enjoys work here, cafe is pretty good cheap food work life balance is ok
cons: computer is a little slow and so many people work here and you don't know which one should be your correct contact, not very efficient work place

headline: Overall 8/10
pros: Benefits are competitive and salary is higher than other FI in average. For entry level jobs, you should be expecting + $2-$3 higher than other FI
cons: Always overtime.....I was a teller in 2014, everyday we had to wait until the balancing teller to finish balancing....thats around 25mins....unpaid

headline: Analyst
pros:
-Great learning experience
-Feel part of the team
-Challenging environment
-Great location at BNS tower
cons: -None that I can think of

headline: Home Financing Advisor
pros: Flexibility to create your own schedule. Work atmosphere is fun and welcoming with colleagues always willing to offer their help.
cons: Rates are not aggressive enough and pricing team not willing to negotiate to secure clients against competitors.

headline: Director Level
pros: A fantastic traditional internal culture embodied in the people, but which is currently under tremendous change as part of a new Corporate Philosophy. Pay is about mid market in Canada and below Industry Standard in the US. Benefits are being reduced with more of the costs being borne by the employee in Canada. In the US, it's still pretty good, but not as good as it was a few years ago.
cons:
Very little communication about how all of the numerous and very recent and also VERY hurried "departures", from the most senior on down, coupled with other changes contribute to the "Strategy" that's been presented.

Alot of uncertainty from within. Huge change always brings that, but more effective communication would mitigate some of that for the employee.

headline: scotiabank ... great company
pros: Great staff, benefits, environment. great place to work
cons: Goals and Targets, but it really rewarding so this might not even be a con

headline: Scotia
pros: The people are amazing! The Scotiabrand logo is recognized everywhere!
cons: The salary is below market value or on the very low end. Technology is very far behind their competition. It is hard illicitng change here. Sr mgmt / directors stuck in their old fashioned ways. Their flex work arrangements are not consistent across the board. Some departments welcome work from home and others dont like it.

headline: Great work environment, poor compensation
pros:
Laid back, but folks get the job done
Not very process heavy compared to other banks
cons:
Not very process oriented
over the top focus on cost initiatives
Vision aligned with bottom line rationalization over top line growth

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Easy to meet target, supportive management team regarding further career opportunity
cons: Low salary, too many paperwork, too much filing.

headline: Personal banking officer
pros: met some amazing people: colleagues and learned a lot
cons: Everyone is a number, pay is too low

headline: Small Business Advisor
pros: It is very hard to get fired as long as you show up for work everyday on time. The expectations of you are very minimal because it is a really menial job despite the job level or description
cons:
Where to begin
- Micromanaged 
- several reports to track every measurable aspect of your job
- extremely poor raises - you could do 250% of your target and get 3% at the end of the year
- very poor structure - tenure is the most important factor when looking to be promoted

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros:
-Happy customers
-Good hours
-Above average pay
cons:
-Lack of patience from supervisors
-Cliquey staff

headline: HR Manager
pros: Large company with a lot of opportunity. Global reach.
cons: Given the size, can be difficult to make a "name for yourself"

headline: Analyst
pros: Very knowledgable workers. Really learned a lot working there as an intern. They were looking to hire full time from internship program so it created good opportunities.
cons: The hours were really long, and some times boring. I had to be there twelve hours a day just to get coffees sometimes. Coworkers were very well compensated though so it made sense why the intern would do it.

headline: Senior Manager, Trade Floor Risk Management
pros: You got oppurtunity to get a whole understanding of risk managment, risk reporting and valuation/P&L attribution, which may not be the responsibility of risk at other banks.  Also, they encourage job shadowing and opportunity to move internally within the same group.
cons: crappy system, crappy data, little training budget and little opportunity to move up.

headline: Manager
pros: - Pros about this company are: compensation, benefits, work-life-balance, versatility to move around in other divisions/departments, location and transportation to head office
cons: Cons about this company are : senior management, many levels of approval required, minimal autonomy to make decisions and mid-management level, turn-around time for decisions are very extensive

headline: better leave sooner than later

headline: Good Place to work

headline: Office politics and drama everyday
pros: The best thing would the perks (discount) that you get as an employee.
cons: Everyone is a manager. Each "manager" has their own plan for you and you never really get the opportunity to actually develop your skills. One might want you to do that while another might want you to just stick to day to day tasks. In addition, there are some very toxic individuals who work there and nobody addresses them. The problem is considered invisible.

headline: A great place to start your career
pros: Scotia is very pro hiring on recent grads.  They have great mentoring programs and will help you develop from the day you start.
cons: it takes a long time to move up through the ranks no matter what your level of education.  If you are willing to wait years to advance than this is the place to be.

headline: senior manager
pros: good people to work with, on public transportation line, no layoffs
cons: slow to advance, compensation less than other banks

headline: Manager's are allowed to bully staff, without any fear of interference from HR.
pros:
- Clients are wonderful! 
- Free bank account and Premium credit cards.
cons:
- ZERO work/life balance.
- EXTREME favoritism. 
- Complete lack of respect for staff privacy rights.
- Manager's allowed to swear at and abuse staff without any fear of reprisal.
- Immigrant staff face bullying to such a degree that it is affecting health and family relationships. If a first generation Canadian makes an honest error, s/he is belittled, reprimanded and written up; in front of staff & customers alike. Any other staff make identical error on same date, it is never noticed.

headline: Great people!
pros: The people are amazing, the company provides a good work life balance, they offer great flexible benefits, a fair salary and flexible work shifts.
cons: There is a lot of workplace politics. The financial objectives are usually set very high and the pressure to meal the targets are high.

headline: Extremely well work environment

headline: nice place to work in Toronto

headline: Best company to work for

headline: Great company with strong leadership.
pros: Extremely low turnover in all departments because of the very high level of employee satisfaction. Great leadership and a "real" open door policy making it easy to approach management with your ideas/issues.
cons: Not a lot of room for upward movement within Roynat Lease Finance. To further your career you'd have to extend your job search to all of Scotiabank. Culture is more "big bank" since Scotia acquired Roynat.

cons: you met get into your comfort zone and stay there so make the effort to move forward

headline: Good place to work
pros:
Strong company values; and excellent team work. The company is invested in leadership development plans. 
Good exposure to strategic projects. Work life balance is achievable in most positions. New CEO is making tuff but needed changes to make the bank more competitive.
cons: Changes being made affect positions and departments and many times not considering the performance of the individuals (for Director and below positions). Salaries are not up to market. Most Sr. Managers don't have opportunity to have staff under making promotion to following step quite hard. Leadership development plan is available at your own time. It is very hard to move positions outside your immediate department / division

headline: experience

cons: no promotions, insignificant pay raise keeps motivation low. Benefits are so so, below average, but that's expected inthis industry.

headline: It's been ok

cons:
Jobs can very monotonous.

headline: Flexible work options
pros: Flexibility and advancement opportunities, annual bonus right before Christmas. ESOP bank matches 50% and most banking fees are waived
cons: Health benefits could be better. A lot of favoritism which makes it hard to advance. Increase core benefits and assist long-term staff with debt consolidation loans for staff that are going thru hardship. Seen too many staff take their personal financial stress to work.

headline: Great atmosphere, the rest is pretty much terrible
pros: Great people, great atmosphere. That is pretty much it.
cons: Terrible salary below average in the banking industry. Terrible benefits compared to industry average. Job volumes keeps increasing, but no salary attached to it.

Training
Good team
good company culture 
fun collegues 
location
cons:
Overworked
no respect for employees
outdated system
